ASSOC_ACTOR_2: NYC: National Youth Coalition; Journalists (Sierra Leone); Lawyers (Sierra Leone); Christian Group (Sierra Leone)
NOTES: On 2 May 2019, military forces and SLPP supporters beat a Sierra Express Media journalist, a civilian head of the NYC, and a Legal Volunteer for the Christian Lawyers Centre, following an APC walkout from Parliament in Freetown. The journalist was attacked after he critized security officials who mishandled an APC supporter and threatened to reveal a video he made.

On 8 September 2019, two female journalists were beaten by the Military Forces of Sierra Leone in Freetown (Western, Western Area Urban), during a football match, by protection bodyguards to the President, Julius Maada Bio.

Around 8 April 2020, 9 soldiers reportedly beat up and injured a journalist in Kenema town, Nongowa subdivision (Kenema, Eastern). The incident took place at a potential coronavirus quarantine venue where the victim was denied entrance. The soldiers started to beat him when he took photos of the place.

On 10 April 2020, 5 police forces reportedly beat up and injured a journalist and took away his phones in Makeni town, Bombali Sebora subdivision (Bombali, Northern) as he was making report about a break into his radio station.

Two Vietnamese reporters from Tien Phong newspaper were attacked in the central province of Ha Tinh when investigating a case of illegal land croachment in Ky Tho commune on Jan 8. These beatings are linked with another beating on the same day of another reporter.

A reporter was seriously beaten while gathering information reports about poultry smuggling in the northern province of Lang Son on Jan 8. He was attacked by seven or eight unidentified men on the road while about 50 others stood by.

Reported on 9 January, two reporters from Tien Phong newspaper were attacked in the central province of Ha Tinh when investigating a case of illegal land croachment in Ky Tho commune, Ky Anh District by local unidentified armed men.
Reported on 9 January, reporter Tran The Dung was beaten up while gathering information reports about poultry smuggling in the northern province of Lang Son by local unidentified armed men.
Two Tien Phong newspaper reporters were attacked in June in Ha Tinh Province while investigating illegal land encroachment, a sensitive political story.

A Lao Dong newspaper reporter was assaulted by several individuals in June while reporting on illegal poultry imports, which was a sensitive political story. The incident of assault was not reported in a specific location, but Lao Dong newspaper is based out of Hanoi.

Vietnamese journalist Le Hoang Hung died from severe burns ten days after being attacked at his home in Tan An town, Long An Province on Jan 20. A man doused him in chemicals and set him on fire. He had written about official misconduct in the Mekong Delta, including instances of cross-border smuggling. UNESCO later ordered further investigation into his death, citing potential human rights violations. His wife was later convicted for the death, although some still believe it was related to his work.
In February Ho Chi Minh City police detained a freelance reporter and allegedly beat him for writing articles critical of government policies.
Two Voice of Vietnam Radio reporters were assaulted and beaten by the police during a search assumed in Hung Yen city (Hung yen province) on April 24.

Two Vietnamese radio reporters from Radio Voice Vietnam were kicked and beaten on May 9 by Hung Yen police while covering the eviction of villagers from their farmland in the province. Reports claim it is state-sponsored violence against journalists.

Three Vietnamese bloggers were injured when a group of government agents (assumed police) smashed the window of their vehicle after following them home in Ho Chi Minh City on July 13. The incident was part of an ongoing trend of harassment reflecting Vietnam's crackdown on dissident bloggers.
Unknown assailants assaulted and beat a reporter assumed in Bien Hoa city (Dong Nai province) on August 14 and deleted pictures on his camera.

Blogger Nguyen Hoang Vi and her family were allegedly beaten by the police while trying to recover a confiscated phone in Phu Thanh Ward, Tan Phu District of Ho Chi Minh City on the afternoon of May 6.

A group of Vietnamese dissidents and their families were attacked by police during a dinner party at a blogger's house in Hanoi City on Sept 25. The police assaulted them, and dragged them away and were finally released.

Authorities in Vietnam beat several dissident bloggers on Human Rights Day after they publicly distributed documents promoting rights and explaining the country's obligations as a signatory to an international convention on torture. In the first incident, a blogger said she, her son and another blogger were walking near her home in Ho Chi Minh City on Dec 11 when plainclothes police approached them, forced them inside their home and beat them.

Authorities in Vietnam brutally beat several dissident bloggers on Human Rights Day (Dec 11) after they publicly distributed documents promoting rights and explaining the country's obligations as a signatory to an international convention on torture. In the third incident that day, two bloggers were beaten by unknown assailants outside the Hoa Minh commune police station in lien Chieu District, Da Nang Province when they arrived to assist fellow online dissidents, who were demanding that authorities return confiscated belongings. One blogger was seriously injured.
The police arrested and beat 2 bloggers on April 19 in Nha Trang city (Khan Hoa province) for attending an event on human rights and police torture.
A Vietnam News Agency reporter was attacked and assaulted by unknown individuals in Tuyen Quang province on October 3.
A Dai Doan Ket newspaper reporter was assaulted by police officers assumed in Hanoi city on October 29.

A freelance journalist narrowly escaped death after being beaten unconscious by eight policemen near Ho Chi Minh City on Nov 25. He was ambushed by the policemen in Thu Dau Mot District and beaten after trying to flee. The motive was unclear.
Blogger Trinh Anh Tuan was attacked and beaten by unknown individuals on April 22 in Hanoi city.
Blogger Nguyen Chi Tuyen was beaten to unconsciousness by unknown assailants in Hanoi city on May 11, assumed police was behind the attack.
Blogger and activist Dinh Quang Tuyen was hospitalized after being assaulted and beaten by police officers in Ho Chi Minh city on May 19.

Two Vietnamese journalists were attacked while filming overloaded trucks carrying heavy loads over a small, weak bridge. The assailants were five young men who beat and kicked the journalists, both of whom suffered head injuries. The young men also stole the journalists' camera before fleeing the scene.

A journalist was badly beaten by plainclothes policemen when he was trying to film a group of policemen checking traffic in Hanoi. Two men took the journalist into a car and beat him. The incident was recorded by bystanders with cell phones, showing the victim bleeding with a number of severe injuries.

Journalist Nguyen Ngoc Quang of Thai Nguyen Province TV was attacked, assaulted and injured by unidentified individuals on September 3. Other journalists attributed the assault to his investigative reports on illegal mining activities in the province.

A journalist and his wife were attacked by two unidentified men with hammers and knives. The journalist suffered eight stab wounds. Some believe the attack was a response to his recent articles on illegal mining in Thai Nguyen province.
Reporter Pham Thanh Tau of Hanoi Moi newspaper was assaulted by the police in Ho Chi Ming city on September 10 while covering a traffic accident.
Police forces arrested and beat several journalists from Luong Tam TV in Hanoi city on September 23.
Local police officers allegedly assaulted a reporter while he was taking pictures of a traffic accident. The reporter was beaten and left bleeding by a group of 10 plain-clothed policemen.
Two journalists were assaulted by an unknown group of people while they were covering a story on pollution.

Between 11-20 January 2017, an activist arrested on 11 January for filming protests outside Taiwan-owned Formosa Plastics Group steel plant on 2 October 2016, was held for nine days at the Ha Tinh police station in Ha Tinh city, Ha Tinh province. The activist claims he was hung by his hands and beaten by eight police officers, who also threw water at his face.
A group of journalists was attacked while covering a story on home and shop builders illegally encroaching public land. One man drove his car into the group of reporters, destroying a camera.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Vietnam (1976-) Prison Guards
NOTES: On 18 August 2018, an activist arrested for filming a protest in front of the Taiwan-owned Formosa Plastics Group steel plant on 2 October 2016 was isolated in a room and beaten and verbally abused in Nghe An province (coded at Vinh, Nghe An province) after being brought to testify at another activist's trial.

On 30 August 2018, in Cam Ranh city, a Vietnamese blogger, who shared a leaked police document on social media,was detained by police at an organized traffic stop and taken into custody for two days, during which he reported being waterboarded and receiving many beatings to try to get him to confess to a crime. He was later released and not charged. At the traffic spot he was traveling with a friend who was beaten when they tried to defend the blogger from being taken away.

On 26 Jan 2019, in Tuyen Quang province, a man, armed with a rock hammer, attacked a journalist from the Vietnam News Agency (VNA), who was reporting on the illegal exploitation of lead and zinc in the northern province.

Since 26 January 2019, a popular blogger has been missing since he fled his home in Da Nang. It is surmised that he was abducted for imprisonment and interrogation. Sources claim the blogger sought asylum in Thailand on 25 January 2019 at the UNHCR in Bangkok, but the Thai government says it has no record of him entering the country.
On 27 Jan 2019, in Kon Tum province, a Vietnam Television (VTV) reporter was attacked and injured by two unknown men.
Somali newspaper originally. Gunmen attack South Mogadishu radio station. Perpetrators unnamed.
Reporters without borders. Sharia court militia attack radio station and journalist.
Radio Shabelle. Unknown men attack Horn Afrik stations.
BBC journalist shot.
one journalist assaulted
one photographer killed in armed attack
Swedish cameraman shot and killed. Unidentified gunmen.

ACTOR1: SSIC: Somali Supreme Islamic Courts Council
NOTES: one journalist kidnapped by icu
one newspaper office severely damaged in attack. perp unkown
one journalist killed, perp unnamed
journalist attacked perp unnamed
one journalist killed perp unnamed
one journalist killed, perp unknown
one reporter targeted in Islamist attack
one journalist killed in armed attack. perp unnamed
a local journalist working with the BBC is shot. it is believed that Islamists are to blame
french journalists threatened with kidnapping unnamed perpetrators
A English journalist and producer was shot and killed outside her hotel in the Somali capital, Mogadishu.
A veteran Somali journalist was wounded in the Somali capital, Mogadishu, when an unidentified gunman fired three times at close range.
A reporter working for HornAfrik Media company has been killed when the car approached a checkpoint near the town of Afgooye. The journalist tried to cover a protest in the area.
Armed militiamen have killed four civilians in Beer Xaano in the outskirts of Kismaayo.

During chaotic scenes at parliament in Hargeysa, policemen whipped reporters and barred them from taking pictures or TV footage of the drama, some cameras were damaged and two reporters were briefly detained.
A female journalist working was badly beaten, tortured and snatched away with guns in Baidoa by armed militias loyal to the speaker of the Somali Parliament Sharif Hassan Sheekh Adan.
An unidentified gunman shot and killed a Swedish cameraman during a demonstration in the Somali capital, a restive city recently captured by an Islamic group after months of fighting.
Three unknown gunmen have murdered a Somali journalist working for an independent radio station in Baidoa.
Transitional government troops based at a market called Darmooley (Heliwa) , outside of Mogadishu have tortured and injured a journalist from Shabeelle Media Network.
Shabelle reporters were beaten and detained briefly by Ethiopian forces in the area.
A journalist was detained and beaten in Hargeisa, the capital of Somaliland.
Unknown gunmen seriously wounded a Somali journalist in his home in Yaqshid neighborhood.
Unknown gunmen killed one of the managers of the independent radio station, Horn Afrik, based in Mogadishu

SOURCE: National Union of Somali Journalists; Shabelle Media Network
NOTES: A journalist in the southwestern province of Gedo, died after gunmen opened fire to the Minibus outside Mogadishu.
A journalist in Beled Weyne suffered injuries after government forces beat him due to the nature of his reporting
The acting chairperson and the vice chairperson of Shabelle Media Network, was assassinated at his home in the Wardhigley district by unknown gunmen.
A French journalist was kidnapped in northern Somalia (otuside Bossaso) by gunmen who apparently were demanding a $70,000 ransom.
A Security guard of Deputy Minister of Security of Puntland Ibrahim Artan (Haji Bakin) had violently beaten a journalist in Bossaso.
Reports from Kismayu town of Middle Jubba region say that the BBCs regional reporter in the region Nasteh Dahir was killed in Kismayu town.
Two freelance journalists, an Australian man and a Canadian woman, were abducted by unidentified armed men near Mogadishu.
Two foreign journalists were kidnapped by unknown assailants in Puntland.
A former Lower Shabelle administration officer shot and killed a local radio reporter.
Somali radio journalist Mohamed Yusuf Ninile was killed while walking to his place of work. It is unknown at this stage whether he was targeted.

10 armed men entered the Sahafi hotel in Mogadishu and removed two French nationals (part of a group of six) claiming to be journalists. The armed men reportedly disarmed the gate guards and then drove for a short distance before changing vehicles and

The National Union of Somali Journalists (NUSOJ) expressed its concern over attacks against two journalists in Bardhere. Mr. Omar Abdirahman Mohamoud (Jaajaa) and Ms. Sahra Ali Mohamoud were seriously beaten on Thursday evening by four masked men shor
At least four journalists have been wounded in north Galkao town in Mudug region after unidentified gunmen attacked three local FM radio stations in the semi-autonomous region of Puntland.
A reporter with Radio Simba was beaten by security personnel in Bossaso Court

Gunmen in the Somali capital killed a veteran journalist working for the state-run radio station Tuesday, and colleagues said they suspect the killing was because of the stations critical view of insurgents.

Sheikh Nur Mohamed Abkey, a reporter at Radio Mogadishu was killed by armed gunmen at Geed Jael in Wardhigley district of Mogadishu.Retrieved www on 05/05/2010, http://www.bbc.co.uk/somali/football/story/2010/05/100504_weriye_abkeey.shtml O1/Journalist killed/ (0/10)/ (00)/Mogadishu/Banadir/20100505.1105
Three gunmen shot dead veteran broadcast journalist Sheik Nur Mohamed Abkey on Tuesday evening as he was returning home from work at the state-run Radio Mogadishu.
Local ASWJ administration arrested Shabelle Radio reporter and allegedly tortured him.
A journalist was killed in the afternoon of Tuesday, 24 August 2010, during gunfire exchange between the Transitional Federal Government and the Islamists group, Al Shabaab, in Mogadishu.
Somali moderate Islamist group [Ahlu Sunna Wal Jamaa] has reportedly tortured Radio Shabeelle reporter in Cabuud Waaq District in central Somalia.
A Somali radio journalist died on Wednesday after being stabbed to death on his way home from work.
A journalist has been wounded in Afgooye District in southern Somalia. Report says that unidentified gunmen wounded the journalist in Afgooye District.

ACTOR1: AMISOM: African Union Mission in Somalia (2007-)
NOTES: 02/09 a Malaysian media crew covering the intervention of a Malaysian charity that had just arrived in Mogadishu was shot at by an AMISOM convoy in the vicinity of K4. One journalist was killed and another injured. The incident probably illustrates the state of tension of the AMISOM soldiers - always under threat of an IED/suicide attack, the absence of visual recognition of humanitarian agencies/journalists and their armed escorts and a possible lack of preparation on the side of many new agencies/charities/journalists who have flooded Mogadishu since the beginning of August.

A female radio journalist working for Radio Galkacyo was shot by unidentified assaulters while returning from work in Garsoor village. The woman, aged 20 and from the Saad/Elmi sub-clan, was hit by four bullets and taken to the GMC hospital for treatment. She is said to have received threat calls over her coverage of the Galgala conflict in the weeks prior to this attack.

Local medias reported that a journalist working with the Codka Nabada Media was shot and injured in Bosasso. The motive of the attempted killing is unknown. The perpetrator fled the scene unidentified.

Abdisalan Sheikh Hassan, a prominent Somali journalist, was shot dead by an unidentified gunman wearing a military uniform while leaving his office in Xamar Jab Jab District in the afternoon of 18/12. The attacker stopped the vehicle of the journalist and shot him in the head. The victim - who was contributing to Horn Cable TV, Xamar Radio and Voice of Democracy Radio - had received several death threats by phone in the days preceding his assassination.

An American-German citizen reported to be a freelance journalist was kidnapped by gunmen while on its way between Galkacyo South and the Galkacyo airstrip in the early afternoon of 21/01. The perpetrators are reported to be part of a pirate group, from the Saad/Niimcaale sub-sub clan. The victim was reportedly travelling in a vehicle belonging to a pirate associated to Mohamed Garfanje, a pirate leader based in Hobyo. The attackers were using a technical and two Land-Cruisers also reported to be belonging to a lieutenant of Mohamed Garfanje. It is believed that the perpetrators benefited from the complicity of the escort used by the victim and were in fact part of the escort the journalist had used when travelling to Hobyo. A Somali-German national who was assisting the journalist and who was trying to protect him was beaten and left on the scene. The victim is believed to have been taken in the direction of Hobyo or Xarar-Dhere. Separate reports indicate that an attempt to kidnap the journalist had already been made when he was staying in Ambassador Hotel in Galkacyo South, before he travelled to Hobyo, but that the management of the hotel had been informed in advance and had beefed up its security to prevent any attack.

Two unidentified gunmen armed with pistols shot and killed the Director of Shabelle Media Network/TV director Mr. Hassan Osman Abdi 'Fantastic' in the evening of 28/01. The victim was en route to his house in Jiro-Miskiin area at the time of the attack.
Two unidentified hitmen armed with pistols shot and killed a former Radio Galkacyo journalist Ali Ahmed Abdi in Israac village on 04/03.
CID officers arrested and beat a reporter of Royal TV in Borama District after accusing him of spreading false information to the public (unspecified). The journalist was later released.

Two unidentified men armed with pistols opened fire at a Radio Shabelle reporter going back to his home in Cinema Mogadishu area (Medina) in the evening of 25/03. The journalist was only slightly injured in the torso. The perpetrators escaped from the scene after local DC militias opened fire at them.
Three masked assailants shot to death Radio Shabelle correspondent in the town of Beletwein of Hiran region, at Howlwadag District around 04:45pm local time, April 5, 2012.
Unidentified armed men kill a journalist.
Two unidentified men shot and killed a journalist near his home.
Unidentified shot and killed a Radio Shabelle journalist.

Two armed men shot and seriously wounded Mohamed Shariif of Bar-Kulan Radio, a UN Funded radio, at hamarjajab district minutes after he left the office Horn Cable television and was heading home on Friday evening around 7:30pm local time. The journalist survived the attack.

The National Union of Somali Journalists (NUSOJ) reports the arrest and beating of two journalists by militias loyal to Ahlu Sunna Waljama administration in Dhusamareb on Tuesday morning on June 12, 2012 around 06:30am local time.

Muhammad Nur Muhammad, known as Sharifka, a journalist working for UN-funded [Nairobi-based] Radio Bar Kulan was injured in Mogadishus Hamar Jajab district on Friday [6 July] evening. Unidentified armed men in Hamar Jajab district shot and seriously wounded Muhammad while he was on his way home in Waberi district, in the latest violent attack on journalists in the country.

Abdulkadir Omar Abdulle, renowned reporter of Universal TV in Mogadishu, was Saturday evening, 7 July 2012, attacked by two men armed with pistols as he was sitting at the garden of his house in Madajir district of Mogadishus Banadir region. After opening fire, Abdulle run into his house, but the armed men pursued and shot him in the stomach and the leg inside his house.
Two unidentified men armed with pistols shot and injured a reporter working for the London-based Somali Universal TV in Korontoda area in Medina District in the evening of 07/07.

An abduction of 2 or 3 International staff or journalists transported in an INGO car occurred while traveling on the road between Burtinle and Bacadwayne. During the abduction fire exchanges occurred, and 3 SPUs are reported injured and hospitalized in Galckayo.

An abduction of 2 or 3 International staff or journalists transported in an INGO car occurred while traveling on the road between Burtinle and Bacadwayne. During the abduction fire exchanges occurred, and 3 SPUs are reported injured and hospitalized in Galckayo.
Two masked gunmen opened fire at a vehicle of an editor of Radio Daljir in Garowe in the evening of 02/0
On Saturday 4 August 2012, Somaliland police in Borame, a town in Awdal region, attacked Hodan Abokor Afi, a female reporter for Somaliland Television (SLNTV)
Somaliland police beat a female journalist working for Somaliland National TV in Borama on 04/08.

Somaliland Police invaded the headquarters of Haatuf Newspaper and beat up the security guard at the newspapers offices then took him to jail. The police also prevented the staff and employees of the newspaper from entering the newspapers offices and said they had orders to do so.

In a separate incident, a broadcast journalist, Mohamoud Ali Yare better known as Buneyste, who is the Nairobi correspondent of the Mogadishu based Radio Hamar - Voice of Democracy - (VoD) - was killed by straying bullet that hit him on the head, while he was watching a football game at a playground at Towfiiq neighborhood of Yaqshid District in Mogadishu on late Sunday afternoon, around 5:30pm,

Three unknown gunmen dressed like school children shot to death Yusuf Ali Osman, a veteran Somali Journalist and former director at the Somalias Ministry of Information, Posts and Telecommunication, several times on the head on Sunday morning

Zakariye Mohamed Mohamud Moallim, a young cameraman working as freelance journalist, was shot dead on Sunday evening in the Nasib Bundo neighbourhood of the Shibis district in Mogadishu. Men armed with pistols shot the journalist in the head and chest

The National Union of Somali Journalists (NUSOJ) mourns the loss of the another prominent journalist who was assassinated in Mogadishu s General Daud High School in Yaqshid neighborhood on Friday noon around 11:30am heightening the dangerous work journalists do in Somalia and bringing the total number of journalists killed this to 13.
Locals say a dead body of Somali journalist was found Thursday in Mogadishus northern restive and volatile Huriwa district, the fifth journalist to be murdered in Somalias capital this month.
A journalist for the Yemeni news agency SABA is killed by armed men while traveling through a volatile region of the city. This comes a day after the murder of a Somali journalist.
Unidentified gunmen shot and injure a journalist. Soldiers in the area fired back at the attackers, but they were able to flee. The victim died in the hospital a week later.
Unidentified gunmen shoot and kill journalist.
A popular poet/comedian who had frequently satirized al Shabaab was shot and killed near his house. He was 18th media figure killed since the beginning of the year.
A Radio Shabelle journalist is assassinated near his home for unspecific reasons. A security sweep of the neighbourhood is launched following the killing.
Somali police attacked and obstructed more than a half-dozen journalists who were seeking to cover a rape trial in Mogadishu. Any political reasons for the obstruction are unknown.
Unidentified gunmen shot and killed a journalist for unknown reason.

Upon gaining control of Garas Weyne from al Shabaab forces, government forces switched off all communication links and killed a Hormuud Telecommunication Company staff for allegedly having ties to al Shabaab.
A journalist for Somali National Television is assassinated outside his home by al Shabaab. The perpetrators were able to escape.
The editor of a newspaper is assaulted with blunt clubs by two hooded men in the evening of 26/04. It is not clear if the attack was politically motivated.
Unidentified masked men tried to kill a freelance journalist in Laas Caanood (Las Anod) on 12/05, but were unsuccessful.

Unidentified armed men shot and wounded a local reporter in Farjano neighbourhood of Kismaayo in the evening of 29/05. The motive behind the attempted assassination is not yet clear but it is believed that it could be connected to his interview with Bare Adan 'Hiraale'- one of the presidents of the Jubaland State.
Al Shabaab executes two people in Baraawe for espionage. Reports indicate that one of the victims was a journalist who used to work for the al Shabaab Radio Al-Furqan and later escaped to Mogadishu.
A journalist is shot and killed in Galkacyo for unknown reasons. It is not clear if the attack occurred in Northern or Southern portion of the city.
Raskamboni forces shot and injured two local journalists in Calanley neighbourhood (Kismaayo) in the morning of 17/07. The two were shot after they refused to stop at a driver checkpoint.
A journalist is killed during the early morning hours by unidentified assailants. The motive for the killing is not known.
A journalist is shot and killed at his home in the Kutuba-Xoor neighbourhood of Shibis.
Police assaulted, then arrested the reporter of the Hargeisa-based Horn Cable TV in Zeylac on 24/08. The reason behind the arrest is currently unclear.

Unidentified attackers armed with pistols attempted to assassinate a local journalist near Indian Ocean University in Bulo Huubey neighbourhood (Medina District) in the evening of 28/09. The journalist reportedly said the gunmen were dressed in government military uniforms and tried to kill him as he walked out of his home. Somali forces arrived after the perpetrators had already escaped.
Unknown gun men attacked and injured television reporter in Medina District. The man died of his injuries several days later.

Police in Lawya Caddo Village (Zeylac District) reportedly assaulted a local a reporter for the Hargeisa-based TV on 20/12 for covering a demonstration staged by local residents and a group of travellers. The demonstrators were reportedly protesting against the new tax rates imposed on commercial vehicles and passengers crossing the border to Djibouti. The reporter managed to escape from the police but they later picked him from his home and detained him. Reports indicate that he was released after two hours.

A security guard of one the presidential candidates in Puntland reportedly assaulted a local TV reporter in Garowe in the morning of 25/12. The incident happened at a time when 10 presidential candidates were holding a meeting in a Garowe.
Reports indicate police in Baidoa assault, detain and torture a Radio Warsan journalist, supposedly for coving an unflattering story.

Unidentified men assaulted and seriously injured a freelance journalist Dayaxa neighbourhood in Ceerigaabo on 07/02. The motive of the attack remains unknown but unconfirmed reports indicate that the attack was related to a report against the mayor. The perpetrators escaped.

Unidentified attackers armed with pistols shot and killed a media worker in Bakaara Market (Hawl-Wadaag District) in the evening of 21/04. The victim was working for the marketing department of Dalsan radio in Mogadishu and a member of the National Youth Association of Somalia. The motive is currently unknown. The perpetrators escaped.
A Mogadishu-based journalist is detained and then killed by government security forces. The motive for the killing is not known.

Somaliland police arrested a local journalist working for Saxafi newspaper at Presidential Palace (Hargeisa) on 08/07 following an attempt to interview Minister of Interior. The police assaulted the detained journalist. Reports indicate that the journalist has been released but police are still keeping his equipment.
A unidentified gunman shot and kill a local journalist for unknown reason in Mogadishu.

Armed militias believed to be Majerten/Isse Mohamud took over control of the state-owned television and radio premise in Garowe in the noon of 05/08. The take-over follows after President Abdiweli Mohamed Gas on 04/08 sacked the director general of the state broadcaster, Ahmed Kismaayo, who is a close relative of the former Puntland president, Abdirahman Mohamed Farole. The militias fired warning shots after Nugal regional police commander tried to access the premise. Traditional elders reportedly stepped in to resolve the matter. A large number of Puntland security forces have been reportedly deployed on the streets of Garowe. Police report gunfire coming from the station, though who it is directed toward is not entirely clear.

Suspected Al Shabaab/Galgala fighters open fire at a vehicle carrying the newly appointed Director of Puntland Television and Radio in Laag village (28km S of Bossaso) in the evening of 02/09. Reports indicate that a Landmine/IED detonated a long side the road followed by gun shoot while driving at Meer Meerka escarpment. The Director escaped unhurt.
Unidentified attackers shot and injured a local journalist in Black Sea neighbourhood (Hodan District) in the afternoon of 12/10. Reports indicate that the victim was the head of Somali Channel TV.
Unidentified gunmen shoot and severely injure a local journalist during an attack in Hawl Wadaag District.
26 October. An unidentified armed group shot and killed a radio journalist working with Radio Dalsan on media freedom in Mogadishu.
A London-based, Somali-born journalist is killed in Galkacyo North by unknown assailants.
A local journalist is believed to have been kidnapped and take to a location near the Ethiopian border.

A policeman at the port of Berbera physically assaulted a local journalist at the gate of the port on 17/12. The incident happened after the journalist who wanted to interview the general manager of the port, had an argument with the policeman for refusing to allow him enter the port. The journalist was reportedly admitted to Berbera Hospital.
A local journalist working for Radio Mogadishu Website was shot and injured by unidentified men armed with pistols near KPP Junction (Hodan District) in the evening of 10/04.

Unidentified men armed with AK47 shot and killed a local radio (Radio Baidoa) reporter and his wife near Unay junction in Berdale neighbourhood (Baidoa) in the night of 30/04. The victims were in their house when the incident happened while a third person (a neighbour) who came out of his house following the gunshot was also killed. The motive behind the killing is currently unknown.

Presidential security guards physically assaulted three local journalists who attempt to cover the departure of SNG prime minister, Umar Abdirashid Ali, from Galkacyo airport on 20/07. The soldiers also reportedly damaged the equipment of the journalists.
A reporter for the English-language newspaper 'Waagacusub' is shot and killed in Dharkeynley district.

Police arrested Somnews TV reporter from his home in Berbera on the morning of 20/09. The reason for his arrest is currently unclear but unconfirmed reports suggest that he issued a report on the privatization of Berbera oil depot. The journalist was assaulted by the police after he reportedly resisted arrest.

Unidentified two men armed with knives onboard of a vehicle reportedly assaulted and stabbed a local journalist working for Waaheen local newspaper in the vicinity of Dahabshiil offices in Farah Omar neighbourhood (Burco) in the morning of 21/10. The motive of the attack remains unknown. The perpetrators reportedly destroyed a laptop and other properties belonging to the victim and later escaped.

A local reporter was reportedly beaten and arrested by the bodyguards of Sanaag regional governor in front of the governors office in Ceerigaabo on 15/10 for allegedly recording news without permission. The reporter was later released.

Somaliland police stormed the residence of a local reporter working for Star TV in Berbera in the morning of 07/12. The police reportedly assaulted the journalist after he refused to cooperate. The reason for the arrest of the journalist remains unknown but reports indicate that it could be linked to a recent report he made against the governor.

Unidentified gunmen attacked a journalist in a drive by shooting in Taleex neighbourhood (Hodan District) in the afternoon of 29/12. The journalist, Omar Faruq Osman, survived the assassination but one of his guards and a civilian bystander were injured in the shooting. The attackers escaped from the scene. No group claimed the responsibility.

Unidentified attackers armed with knives and other crude weapons reportedly assaulted a freelance journalist in Buuhoodle on 08/01. The motive behind the attack is currently unknown. The perpetrators escape while the victim was later admitted to Manhal Hospital in Laas Caanood.
Gunmen suspected of belonging to al Shabaab group shot and killed a female journalist working for state-run Radio Mogadishu on 05/06.

Unidentified gunmen armed with Pistols reportedly shot and killed a famous Mullah (Aidid Hassan Hussein) who was allegedly working with a Government TV station at Israac village in Hamarjajab District. The Victim was shot as he came out of Mosque after isha pray. The motive of the assassination is not yet clear and attackers managed to escape.
Al Shabaab executed two men accused of killing journalists 'several months ago.'
A prominent businessman from La Anod was attacked and severely wounded shortly after he had supported journalists to report on resistance to voter registration in Awrbogays
Unidentified gunmen shoot and kill a journalist, along with his wife at their home in Baidoa.
A reporter for a newspaper is attacked and injured by unknown assailants.
Unidentified gunmen assassinate a journalist in Mogadishu.
An SL local TV Journalist was severely beaten by Lasanod Mayor's Guards as he pressed to interview the Mayor despite his refusal.

Unidentified gunmen kidnap and torture local journalist. Perpetrators not known. The source reports the journalist received deaths threats a day earlier. The victim escaped the following day after the abductor's vehicle broke down.

A Somali radio journalist working for the state media was shot and injured while on his way to office by a security guard near Villa Somalia. The victim was rushed to hospital for treatment. The motive of the incident was not clear. The perpetrator was arrested.
Unidentified gunmen shoot and kill a journalist and a second person in Mogadishu.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Somalia (2017-) National Intelligence and Security Agency
NOTES: Three NISA soldiers on duty at Dabka junction road neighbourhood mistakenly shot at a journalist whom they had suspected to be al Shabaab. The journalist also suspected the undercover soldiers to be al Shabaab militants and attempted to escape. The journalist was eventually arrested by the undercover soldiers and was allegedly tortured. Police officers later arrived at the scene and identified the victim as a journalist. The journalist was taken for medical treatment after receiving multiple gunshot wounds.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Somalia (2017-) Puntland Security Force
NOTES: Puntland soldiers beat Garowe journalist Khalif Guelle Aden. Motives unknown.
04 April. Security forces attack journalists outside the Parliament building. The reporters were covering a governing dispute.

27 June. Unidentified gunmen attempt to assassinate Somali journalist Farhiyo Mohamud Mire near Dabka Junction. The assailants escaped the scene. The victim survived. The motives behind the incident are unknown.
28 June. A female journalist is assassinated by suspected al Shabaab gunmen near Dabka Junction, Hawl Wadaag.
28 June. A female journalist is assassinated by unidentified gunmen near Dabka Junction, Mogadishu.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Somalia (2017-) Jubaland Security Force
NOTES: 09 July. Interim Juba Administration soldier fired on journalist Yahya Abdirisak Soofe. The journalist was not injured.

On 26 July, a cameraman working for a media company was reportedly shot and killed by an armed government soldier in Suuqa Beerta vicinity, Waberi district. According to the report, the shooting came after a dispute over road access. The soldier fled the scene after the incident.
26 July. An unidentified gunman assassinated a journalist in Xamar Jaabjab. Dalsan Radio report the perpetrators were government soldiers.
19 September 2018: A reporter was stabbed to death in Galkaco town, Mudug region, by an unidentified group of youth. The reason behind the stabbing is not clear.
27 October. Unknown armed men shot and killed a journalist of a local radio at Elasha-Biyaha settlement in Afgoye district.
18 November. After a grenade attack on a police station in Galkayo, journalist Farhan Farah Abdi of Radio Jareiban, was stabbed by unknown attackers.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Somalia (2017-) Puntland Police Force
NOTES: 08 December. A Puntland Policeman Deeq Muse Cise 'Dooroqoosh' fired on Radio Daljir Director Ahmed Tallman in Garowe, who was uninjured in what is being described as an attempted assassination.
18 February. Three officers physically abused a journalist in Mogadishu streets. Three days later they were arrested.
27 February. Some journalists were attacked and injured by a police officer. They were also detained for a while and later released.
21 April. Journalists working for several media companies in Hargeysa were assaulted and arrested by Somaliland police. The motive of the arrest is unknown.
14 May. A journalist was attacked and arrested by Somaliland police in Laascaannod. Reason unknown.
27 May. Journalist Ali Adan Mumin, a reporter of the Goobjoog News was reportedly assaulted and arrested in Mogadishu.
08 October. In Hargeysa, Somali police forces have reportedly assaulted and arrested the Director for Universal Television for an unknown reason.
27 October 2019. Five journalists working for various Somali media outlets have been beaten and arrested by Somali police in Mogadishu when they were covering protests on road closures.
04 November 2019. In Hodan district, police opened fire on a car carrying journalists from the international news agencies. Journalists said they were tortured too. No fatalities reported.
On 16 February 2020, an unknown armed group shot dead a Somali journalist in Afgooye (Afgooye, Lower Shebelle). The journalist worked for Radio Kumliye and the London-based Universal Television.
On 24 February 2020, Al Shabaab militants abducted a Radio Afgoye reporter at Hawo Tako village (Belet Weyne, Hiraan). His whereabouts or situation is not known.

On 4 May 2020, unidentified man armed with a knife stabbed a famous Kalsan TV journalist to death at the Seybiano village in Mogadishu-Hodan district (Hodan, Banadir). The motive for this murder is not clear and perpetrator attempted to escape from the scene, but District Police Forces arrived and arrested him to CID for further interrogation.

On 25 June 2020, a male journalist was shot and injured by a Govt soldier (military) manning a security checkpoint in the Seybiano neighbourhood of Mogadishu-Hodan district (Hodan,Banadir). The victim was reportedly rushed to hospital for treatment.
On 1 October 2020, a government soldier shot and injured a journalist near Luga-baxsi restaurant in Horseed neighborhood in Baidoa town (Baydhaba, Bay).

On 19 February 2021, government police forces (Haram cad unit) attacked a radio Bandhiga journalist and director while broadcasting live anti-government protests organized by the opposition in Mogadishu - Wadajir district (Wadajir, Banadir).
On 1 March 2021, Al Shabaab militants shot and killed a well-known former journalist in Israac village (Gaalkacyo, Mudug).
On 27 April 2021, government security forces raided the office of Mustaqbal radio and assaulted several journalists in Mogadishu (Banadir).

On 16 May 2021, government police assaulted a Radio Kulmiye journalist while she was covering parents protesting against the Somali government at Daljirka Daahsoon junction in Mogadishu - Bondhere district (Banadir).
A political editor was shot in a hijacking incident in Tladi, Soweto. The attack was apparently related to a story he had written.
A prominent journalist is shot and killed by intruders. It is unclear is this action was that of coincidence or of a more elaborate motive.
An editor of a Zimbabwean newspaper, living in Johannesburg, is killed in his home. It is unclear if this was a random attack, or revenge for an unfavorable article printed in his paper.
An unknown person shoots and kills a freelance journalist in his home. It is unclear if this was a random act of violence, or a political assassination. Polokwane is in South Africa
Tow newspaper reporters are found dead. It is unclear if this violence is coincidental, or connected to an unfavorable article they printed.
A journalist narrowly escaped an attack from a gunman.
A newspaper editor is shot dead by unknown gunmen. It is unknown if this killing is coincidental or related to unfavorable articles published by he and his newspaper.
A group of armed men kill a Somali journalist. It is unclear if the motive for violence was a robbery or other.

ACTOR1: ANCYL: African National Congress Youth League
NOTES: ANCYL supporters ran riot, attacking journalists, pelting the police with stones and burning posters bearing pictures of President Jacob Zumas face. They were mainly supporters of Julius Malema. Police respond with rubber bullets. One police officer reported injured.
Man attacks freelance journalist during ANC conference
Political reporter attacked by unknown men allegedly in retaliation for his coverage of political matters in the area
Police assault journalist covering mob attack on ANC provincial chairman
Security guard attacks journalist outside hospital where Nelson Mandela was receiving treatment
A group of ANC supporters threaten a DA party chair during a political news event and assault a television news crew.
Two journalists and two members of a staunch anti-mining group on the Transkei Wild Coast were allegedly assaulted in Bizana when they were attacked at about 5pm.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters; Journalists (South Africa)
SOURCE: African News Agency; AFP; News24 (South Africa)
NOTES: A group of men armed with sjamboks, knobkerries, pointed sticks and golf clubs and believed to be ANC members have attacked EFF members and the media during a visit to Sethokga Hostel in Tembisa, on the East Rand.

On 15 May 2020, a journalist accused police of assault in Meqheleng informal settlement in Ficksburg (Thabo Mofutsanyana, Free State) while covering a story and again when he went to open a case at the police station.
Standard reporter Ray Choto arrested, tortured in custody, to international condemnation

ACTOR1: ZANU-PF: Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front
NOTES: Photographer of Chronicle newspaper assaulted while photographing clash between ZAPU and Zanu-PF

NOTES: ZANU-PF abduct and harass journalist

2 journalists apparently assaulted in police custody after being arrested in connection with City Council protest
2 Al-Jazeera journalists assaulted, arrested

Two journalists with the Harare-based daily tabloid 'H-Metro', were reportedly assaulted by youth members of the Church of Central Africa Presbyterian (CCAP) on 14 November 2010 in Harares township of Mbare.

ACTOR1: ZANU-PF: Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front
NOTES: Newsdays Masvingo correspondent, Tatenda Chitagu, claimed on Tuesday [7 December] he was assaulted on Sunday by ZANU PF [ZimbabweAfrican National Union -Patriotic Front] youths at the instigation of politburo member Dzikamai Mavhaire.

ACTOR1: ZANU-PF: Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front
NOTES: MUNN Marketing, the distributors of three Alpha Media Holdings three newspapers and several other leading South African publications, says attacksagainst its vendors by Zanu PF supporters and suspected state agents have intensified countrywide.

Media rights groups have expressed their shock and condemnation after a journalist, who is 6 months pregnant, was assaulted by a man who boasted about being related to a director of the Central Intelligence Organisation (CIO).
After re-opening following a seven-year ban, a Daily News reporter was assaulted by MDC-T during an interview at MDC party headquarters.

ACTOR1: ZANU-PF: Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front
NOTES: ZANU-PF storms parliament and beats legislators and journalists; police look on but do nothing

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: MDC: Movement for Democratic Change (Tsvangirai Faction); Journalists (Zimbabwe)
NOTES: Independent media and MDC claim that police disrupted rally using violence and intimidation
Soldiers in civilian clothes attack journalist covering census training exercise
ANC aides to Julius Malema assault Zimbabwean journalists covering his visit to Harare
Businessman and three of his friend assault journalist reporting on scam the man had orchestrated at his company

NOTES: MDC security personnel attack journalist

ACTOR1: MDC: Movement for Democratic Change (Tsvangirai Faction)
NOTES: MDC security personnel attack journalist
Freelance journalist abducted and assaulted by unknown group

Unidentified arsonists attempt to set the buildings of two state run media outlets, Chronicle and Sunday News, alight during the early morning hours. The attackers reportedly hurled a flammable liquid at a disused wooden door leading to the newspapers advertising department and set it on fire before fleeing into the night. No causalities or injuries reported, though it is not clear if anyone was present at the time of the attack. Exact date of the attack is not clear.

ACTOR1: ZANU-PF: Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front
NOTES: Several journalists were roughed up by ZANU-PF youth at a Bulawayo Press Club meeting
A journalist is beaten and detained by police when filming an assault by the police force on local traders.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: ZANU-PF: Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front
NOTES: Journalists covering the protest in Chitungwiza are assaulted by police, leading to one journliast being hospitalised.
Police beat a freelance journalist after he photographs police beating a suspected thief.
Bulawayo police on Thursday assaulted freelance journalist who was taking photographs of skirmishes between ZRP officers and commuter omnibus operators.
A Journalist was assaulted by police forces during clashes in Chitungwiza.

ACTOR1: ZANU-PF: Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: MDC: Movement for Democratic Change (Tsvangirai Faction); Journalists (Zimbabwe)
NOTES: A private media journalist and scores of MDC-T supporters were assaulted and forced to flee for their after being attacked by Zanu PF activists in Highfields, Harare.

ACTOR1: ZANU-PF: Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front
NOTES: A journalist was reportedly attacked by Zanu PF activists while covering a war veterans solidarity march at Zanu PF headquarters in Harare.
During demonstrations in Harare, police assaulted journalists who were covering the protests.
A student activist and a journalist were ambushed and assaulted by 12 unknown men in Harare
Police beat a journalist who had been arrested with his colleagues.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Zimbabwe (1987-2017) Central Intelligence Organization
NOTES: A state agent assaulted a journalist who took a photograph of a car emblazoned with Mugabe's image.
The military beat 2 reporters at the national broadcasting station, prior to taking control of the airwaves.

On December 12th, police arrested two journalists in Harare, and beat one of them with truncheons. They were released without charge later that same day, although their camera equipment had been damaged as well as confiscated.
On January 9th, a journalist was heavily assaulted by unknown assailants for filming police officers who were assaulting vendors.

On April 2nd, members of the Zimbabwe Republic Police fired a teargas canister at the headquarters of '263 Chat' in Harare, after the journalists filmed council police and ZRP officers chasing vendors. No casualties reported.

On 4 April 2020, a freelance journalist was reportedly assaulted by police in the Harare suburb of Kuwadzana. He was arrested, assaulted and forced to delete picture he took of a police operation (Harare).
On 11 April 2020, police reportedly assaulted a journalist in Harare (Harare) during the national coronavirus lockdown enforcement.
On 25 June 2020, two journalists were assaulted and injured by soldiers in Warren Park (Harare) during the national coronavirus lockdown.

On 30 July 2020, a journalist was abducted and reportedly tortured by the Ferret Team (branch of national military) in Bulawayo (Bulawayo, Bulawayo). He was released three days later and admitted to a private clinic, which reported that they were observing the journalist for poisoning.
The Director of Catholic Radio Good News, Fr. Don Bosco Ochieng, was physically attack by unknown group of people at around 10pm on Tuesday night in Rumbek market,
South Sudanese political commentator is shot dead in front of his house in Juba by an unidentified armed group

Police beat up a journalist whilst he was leaving the National Parliament building. The journalist was delivering newspapers. As a result of intimidation by the police, CTV and Citizen Newspaper have closed their operations.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: UNMISS: United Nations Mission in the Republic of South Sudan (2011-); Journalists (South Sudan)
NOTES: National Security Service forces detained 2 national UNMISS staff, including a security guard and a journalist from Radio Miraya, in Wau, reportedly accusing them of having links with rebels. The security guard was taken to Juba the next day and initially detained at the NSS riverside detention facility. In early 2015, he was transferred to the NSS headquarters in Jebel, and in January 2016, he was transferred back to the NSS riverside detention facility. Any access to him has been denied since December 2015. He has allegedly been subjected to torture or other ill treatment while in NSS detention.
A journalist was allegedly beaten while being detained by the police.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of South Sudan (2011-) Presidential Security Unit
NOTES: Members of the 'presidential guard force' assaulted and detained a journalist working for Bloomberg.
13 people killed, including 5 journalists for South Sudan state-run media, when suspected LRA opened fire on a 2-car convoy driving through Kubri Modabal, Raja county.
A Radio Tamazuj journalist and another man shot dead by unknown gunmen in Akobo.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Journalists (South Sudan); Didinga Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Prisoners (South Sudan)
NOTES: On 6 August 2015, two civilians and a journalist (linked to Gurtong Media) were detained and tortured after being arrested by SPLA in Chukudum in Budi county (Eastern Equatoria state). After being transferred to different military facilities on or after 15 August 2015, the victims were not heard from again. All victims presumed to be of Didinga ethnicity.
Gunmen shoot dead a journalist in Juba, less than a week after Salva Kiir threatened to kill any journalists working against the government.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
NOTES: NSS arrested a journalist in Juba for criticizing in an article SPLM's human rights record. He was held in incommunicado detention at the NSS headquarters in Juba until his release in February. While in detention, he was subjected to torture and other ill-treatment.
Journalist kidnapped and tortured in Juba, released the next week.
Journalist shot and wounded by suspected soldier in Wau.
Journalist kidnapped and beaten, and released alive near a graveyard in Juba.

Six unidentified gunmen in uniform kidnapped a journalist and his brother in their family home in Kerepi village along the Juba-Nimule road. The journalist was killed soon after but his death was only uncovered three months later, in September. Witnesses say the suspects were wearing Tiger Batallion uniforms, from the Presidents guard.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of South Sudan (2011-) Presidential Security Unit
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Journalists (South Sudan); Aid Workers (South Sudan)
NOTES: A force of between 80-100 uniformed soldiers believed to be a part of the Presidential Guard (Tiger Battalion) overran the upscale Terrain Hotel a residential complex for the staff of international organizations. Over a four-hour period, they beat and abused many of the residents, raped and gang-raped at least five international aid workers and an unknown number of staff working at the compound, and executed a Nuer employee of a non-governmental news organization in an ethnically targeted killing. The soldiers damaged every single room and looted the compound extensively, stealing over 25 vehicles. Later in October, eight people were accused of rape, eight others of looting and one of injuring a victim, most from the SPLA.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of South Sudan (2011-) National Security Service
NOTES: A reporter for the daily Al-Maugif was reportedly abducted and badly beaten and burnt by South Sudans National Security Service. The abductees accused him of criticizing the president on social media, as he had just published an article on the crisis and corruption undermining South Sudans economy. He was dumped in Jubas Gumba cemetery three days after he went missing.
Unknown gunmen shot dead the finance manager of catholic radio service Bakhita FM and member of the Community Media Network at Munuki residential area of Juba. Reasons are unclear.

On 19 May 2020, armed men entered the house of a journalist in Juba, and stole various items (including a work laptop and mobile phones) from the premises. Upon leaving, they shot the brother of the journalist (who was outside the house) twice in the leg.
On 1 July 2020, unknown gunmen shot and killed a radio journalist as he travelled within Tonj South county to Tonj town (Warrap state). There is no further information.

On 19 June 2021, police severely beat two journalists working for the Catholic Radio Network at a police station in Rumbek town (Rumbek Centre county, Lakes state). The two were lashed 50 times with a cane, after they went to the station to enquire about the recent arrest of a local artist.

A journalist survives an assassination attempt. Khartoum newspapers Tuesday reported that three unnamed persons have so far been taken in custody for suspected involvement in the assassination attempt, which is widely believed to have been perpetrated by the opposition Peoples National Congress party of Hassan al-Turabi.
The GoS accused Darfur rebels of kidnapping 4 journalists from the Darfur television network (specific locations not given).
Riot police fired tear gas and beat a journalist as opposition party supporters gathered to demonstrate against a recent rise in petrol and sugar prices.
Sudanese security forces fired tear gas and beat demonstrators protesting against price increases for basic goods, and a journalist was found beheaded in a further sign of rising political tensions.

Armed security agents on Friday raided the AFP bureau in Khartoum and arrested a correspondent who had taken pictures of the protests. Two agents from the National Intelligence and Security Service (NISS), one of them wielding a pistol seized the journalist and kept him in custody for more than 12 hours without charge.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
NOTES: Al Sudanese freelance journalist was found on the side of a road in Khartoum after being reported missing on 29 October. The journalist had been detained and tortured by agents from the National Intelligence and Security Services (NISS)

Also, award-winning novelist Rania Mamoun was arrested on Monday and released on Tuesday afternoon. A photo of her that circulated on social media shows obvious signs of beating and torture on her face and left eye, as the website Girifna reported.
Police forces arrested and tortured a journalist from El Jareeda newspaper in En Nahud

ACTOR1: Hamza Combat Group Against Atheism and Heresy
NOTES: Masked gunmen raided the offices of Al-Tayyar daily newspaper and severely beat its chief editor, reportedly over his calls for normalisation of ties with Israel. A group calling itself 'Hamza Combat Group Against Atheism and Heresy' claimed responsibility for the attack and threatened to hunt down anyone 'openly hostile to the Palestinian resistance'. The editor later claimed that the Hamza group does not exist and is hiding the real attackers.
A Sudanese journalist was allegedly tortured and beaten for two days of his detention between Sept.25 and Oct.1 after being picked up during protests ahead of the anniversary of the 2013 movement.
Masked men attack a journalist and publisher of al-Mustaqilla newspaper at his house in Khartoum, following publication of columns criticizing White Nile state government.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Rapid Support Forces
NOTES: A British journalist and his Darfur translator were abducted by RSF members in Darfur while investigating reports of chemical use against civilians in Jebel Marra between January and August 2016 by Amnesty International. They were detained and allegedly tortured for two months first in North Darfur and then at Kober prison in Khartoum.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
NOTES: A female journalist from Al-Jareeda newspaper was assaulted by officials from the NISS as she was investigating the removal of a residential district in the south of Khartoum. She was also reportedly beaten during interrogation.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
NOTES: NISS officers assaulted a journalist from Assayha newspaper as she was investigating the victims of a traffic accident in Turkish hospital. She was detained at the hospital for three hours and forced to write a statement saying that she would never enter the hospital for professional purposes again.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
NOTES: NISS officers assaulted a journalist from Assayha newspaper as he was investigating allegations of assault by NISS and police personnel on women working in selling food and tea. They confiscated his mobile phone and detained him at the police station.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
NOTES: NISS beat and detained three journalists and an activist in Khartoum. Three of them were leaving the premises of a courtroom where they attended the trial of several civil society activists.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) Prison Guards
NOTES: In December 2016, a British journalist and his American-Sudanese translator, who entered Darfur to investigate Amnesty International's report that Sudanese security forces used chemical weapons against civilians in Jebel Marra, were detained for nearly two months and severely tortured with beatings, electric shocks, and mock executions.

Security forces reportedly prevented journalists from entering Khartoum's airport to cover the return of Imam El Sadig El Mahdi, the President of the National Umma Party, after an exile of more than two years abroad. At least one journalist was beaten and detained. Delegations of people coming from White Nile and Sennar states were also reportedly blocked from entering Khartoum city to see the leader, but allowed in later after the end of the reception ceremony.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
NOTES: In March, NISS arrested and beat a journalist covering the trial of a civil society activist for allegedly obstructing him from carrying out his duties. She was sentenced to a 10,000 Sudanese pounds fine or a four-month jail term four months later, on 10 July.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
NOTES: Demonstrations broke out in El Jareif West, Khartoum, after a death sentence was issued against four people accused of killing the former director of the Sudan Cotton Company three years ago. Police slapped and violently arrested a journalist covering the protest. She was later beaten and verbally abused in detention by NISS officers.
A journalist is targeted and assaulted by security forces while covering protests. The journalist was then detained for several days where reports of torture occurred.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
NOTES: On December 25th, and during demonstrations in Khartoum, journalists from multiple networks were assaulted by plain clothes security agents (coded here as NISS). Additionally, journalists had mobile phones confiscated, and pictures were deleted.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
NOTES: On January 13th, NISS agents - as well as masked men in plain clothes (recorded here as UAG) - were reported to have beaten three journalists covering protests in Khartoum North. One journalist was also detained, but was released later the same day.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
NOTES: On January 14th, NISS agents arrested 28 journalists in Khartoum, to prevent them from staging a sit-in by the NISS headquarters. Some of the journalists were reportedly beaten, though have now been released. Separately, a doctor was arrested in Nyala (South Darfur) the same day, and another doctor was arrested in Omdurman on 11th Jan. A student activist was also arrested in Ed Damazin (Blue Nile) on the 13th Jan.

On January 16th, security forces (some who were plan-clothes officers (recorded as UAG), and one wearing a military uniform, recorded as army) forced their way into the house of a journalist in Omdurman, after threatening to fire tear gas into it. After the journalist let the men in, they beat her in front of her children.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
NOTES: On January 17th, an unspecified number of journalists were arrested in Khartoum whilst covering protests. They were reported to have been taken to two different detention centres in Khartoum and were beaten by unspecified security services (coded here as NISS).

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-2019) National Intelligence and Security Services
NOTES: On April 6th, NISS agents detained five journalists working for Al Jazeera in Khartoum (note the nationalities of the journalists are not specified; journalists coded as Sudanese pending further information). The journalists were taken to an undisclosed location and beaten, and were released the following day.

On July 17th, a prominent blogger was assaulted and his equipment and passport confiscated by two security personnel (coded here as police) in Khartoum. The blogger sought refuge in the Ethiopian embassy.

On July 24th, the house of the editor of El Baath newspaper was attacked by a group of unknown armed men in Khartoum. The source does not specify whether there were any injuries. The offices of the paper were ransacked by an unknown group on July 29th.

On 21 June 2020, police arrested and severely beat a journalist who was taking pictures of vehicles queuing at a petrol station whilst covering fuel shortages in Suakin (Red Sea state). The incident is one of several instances of harassment directed towards journalists in Red Sea state the same week.

Around 25 October 2020, a journalist was abducted by men in military uniform (and coded as such) outside the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Khartoum. The attackers beat the journalist, and then robbed him.

Around 27 May 2021 (as reported), a journalist was reported to have been beaten and verbally abused by police in Bahri in Khartoum North (Bahri locality, Khartoum state). There is no further information.

On 22 June 2021, a freelance journalists was detained and then tortured by Sudan Liberation Forces Alliance (a signatory to the Juba Peace Agreement) soldiers was filming at UNAMID Supercamp Nyala (Nyala Shimal locality, South Darfur state), before being released following the intervention of the Governor of South Darfur. During his detention, the journalists was able to communicate with another civilian who had been arbitrarily detained by the group for four days.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Sudan (2019-) Military Intelligence Service
NOTES: On 23 August 2021, members of the Military Intelligence service assaulted a journalist and another person, who were seriously injured, near the army headquarters in Khartoum (Khartoum state).
On 28 August 2021, members from the regular armed forces attack a journalist in Khartoum (Khartoum state). The Sudanese Journalists Network condemned the act by forces and called for press freedom.
On 19 September 2021, a lieutenant in the police assaulted and confiscated items from a journalists at the Democrat newspaper in Khartoum (Khartoum state).

On 19 October 2021, members of the SLM/A-Minnawi Faction assaulted journalists (including AFP photographers and the crew of Al Jazeera) during their coverage of the ongoing sit-in protest at the palace in Khartoum (Khartoum state). Some photographers were harassed and beaten.
Suspected hijackers shot and killed the editor of a newspaper, the Swazi Observer.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: ANCYL: African National Congress Youth League; COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions
NOTES: Journalists covering a story about Swali prisons are assaulted have their camera taken by correctional officers.
On 12 March 2020, a journalist accused police of arresting and torturing him in Manzini (Manzini North, Manzini) after he published an article criticising the king.
Around 15 March 2020 (month of), a journalist was arrested and tortured by Swazi police for an alleged act of sedition in Mbabane (Mbabane East, Hhohho). He later fled to South Africa.

On 23 April 2020, a journalist sustained head injuries after he was assaulted by eSwatini police officers, who came to his home and detained him in Nhlangano (Maseyisinj, Shiselweni). His arrest is allegedly related to critical articles he published about King Mswati.

SOURCE: Daily Sun (South Africa); Times (South Africa); News24 (South Africa)
NOTES: On 4 July 2021, two South African journalists were arrested by members of the military forces, tortured, and later released near the city of Matsapha (Manzini North, Manzini).

On 26 February 2020, a Chechen regime critic and blogger was attacked and hit on the head with a hammer in Gavle by a Russian man. He got hold of the hammer and hit the attacker. A Russian woman has been arrested for assisting with the attack. In June 2020, another person has been arrested. Police believe a foreign power could be behind the attack.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Military Forces of Pakistan (2018-); ISI: Inter-Services Intelligence
NOTES: Around 2 March 2020, a Pakistani journalist went missing in Uppsala. Reported in April 2020, Reporters Without Borders believe the journalist was abducted by direct orders from Pakistani intelligence services, ISI. His body was found on 23 April 2020.
On 13 March 2020, a female journalist was assaulted with a knife and stabbed several times in the face and head at her front door in Pitea by an unknown female perpetrator.
On 10 January 2017, the body of a media activist was found in Tafas following his kidnapping by unknown militiamen.
South African photojournalist Shiraaz Mohamed has been kidnapped in the north western of Syria.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: HTS: Hayat Tahrir al Sham; Jaysh al Nasr; Opposition Rebels (Syria); Al Wosta Division; Journalists (Syria)
NOTES: 172 bodies were found of people executed by Liwa al Aqsa before they left the Khan Shaykun area and Al-Latamna. 81 fatalities were coded priviously in Murak and Khan Shaykun, the remaining 91 are divided on Khan Shaykun and Al-Latamna as 46 and 45 respectively and some of them are from Hayat Tahrir al-Sham, Jaysh al Nasr, other FSA rebels and civilians. More specific reports indicate 11 commanders, 56 fighters and 3 media activists from Jaysh al Nasr were executed as well as at least 10 fighters of the Free Syrian Army Al Wosta Division 'Al-Wosta'.
As reported on 22 February 2017, a media activist was shot, and his dead body was found in al Khazanat area, following his arrest by Liwa al Aqsa on February 8, 2017.

Jaish Al-Islam members assaulted the media activist Yaser Al-Dumani in Eastern Ghouta of Rural Damascus, and they also sent a direct killing threat to the media activist Hadi Al-Mnajed. Neither injuries nor fatalities were reported.
IS shot and killed a media activist in Jellin village in Daraa, while he was covering the clashes between rebels factions and IS as part of 'Dahr Al-Boghat' battle.
Unknown militiamen assassinated a media activist in al-Yarmok area west of Tal Shihab, by shooting him when he was driving his car.
Following his capture on May 6th by regime forces during clashes he was covering in Hama province with rebels, a media activist was executed by regime forces.
ANNA reporter Oleg Blokhin was wounded in Deir-ez-Zor. Neither injuries nor fatalities were reported.
On 13 May, 2017, PYD security forces arrested the Kurdish journalist Barzan Hussein in Rmelan city of Al-Hasakak governorate. Neither injuries nor fatalities were reported.
HTS attacked media activists at one of their checkpoints located in the countryside of Al-Quneitra and then confiscated the photography equipment and took them to an unknown destination.
1 male media activist was found dead on the road to Dahr al-Jabal area just east of As-Sweida city having died under unknown circumstances.

On 13 August 2017, members of Jaysh al Islam physically assaulted members of the Violation Documenting Center and damaged and stole their belongings in Duma city in Rural Damascus. There were no fatalities.
HTS arrested the media activist and athlete Ahmad al Hunayni in Kafr Nabl city in Idlib.

IS executed 1 male civilian using small arms fire in Al Mayadin in southern Deir-ez-Zor countryside under accusations of unpermitted media work following his detainment several days prior from an internet cafe. The victim was an administrator of 'Al Mayadin Today' Facebook page. IS also prevented his family from hosting a funeral.
The Islamic State executed a 17-year-old boy in Al Mayadin city after arresting him on the accusation of 'illegitimate media work'.
The Democratic Union for two days have arrested more than 50 journalist and political activist in different areas of Al Hasakeh city and Quamishli. No fatalities reported.
The Democratic Union for two days have arrested more than 50 journalist and political activist in different areas of Al Hasakeh city and Quamishli. No fatalities reported.
A Kurdish journalist who was wounded in Deir ez-Zor died in Hasakeh.
On 10 November 2017, the body of a media activist was found in the town of Jasim.
On 31 March 2018, Sultan Murad Division fighters detained a Kurdish journalist in the city of Azaz.

The body of a media activist from the Idleb countryside was found near the Syrian-Turkish border, as he was reported missing in Aqrabat five days before being killed. Turkish border guards were accused of killing him as he attempted to cross the border.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Syria (2000-) Prison Guards
NOTES: Two civilians, including a media activist, were tortured and killed in an unidentified regime detention centre in Al-Hasakeh province.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Syria (2000-) Prison Guards
NOTES: Two civilians, including a media activist, were tortured and killed in an unidentified regime detention centre in Damascus city.
Unidentified gunmen kidnapped a media activist in northern Homs province.
On 9 November 2018, Sultan Murad Division fighters arrested a media activist while filming in the Afrin countryside. During his detention he was severely tortured. He was released on 12/11/2018.

Hayat Tahrir al Sham carried out a number of raids and arrests in Kafr Zeita in Hama. A former commander of the Free Syrian Army was arrested and a civilian was injured during an HTS raid on the house of a local journalist. No fatalities were reported.

SOURCE: SNHR; Liveuamap; ProtectDefenders.eu; Front Line Defenders; SOHR
NOTES: On 23 November, 2018, an unidentified armed group opened fire and killed activist-journalists Ra'ed al-Fares and Hammoud Junaid, in Kafr Nobol in Idleb. Total fatalities coded as 2.

On 10 December 2018, unidentified armed individuals discharged SAF from their vehicle towards the As-Sweida Al-Hadath media outlet studios in the city of As-Sweida and fled the scene of the attack. Neither fatalities or casualties were reported.
Unidentified gunmen abducted a media activist in the town of Salqin.
On 28 March 2019, unidentified gunmen opened fire on a car of media activists while it was traveling through the Al Bab area with neither injuries nor fatalities reported.

Around 15 April 2019 (as reported), the body of a media activist who had carried out a reconciliation deal with the regime and had been arrested at a regime checkpoint was found dead with gunshot wounds on the road between Yadudeh and Mzeireb villages in the northern countryside of Dar'a governorate.

On 4 June 2019, QSD forces detained a journalist working for the regime-affiliated Syrian New Channel (Al-Ikhbariyah Suoria) in the city of Quamishli on charges of making news reports that served the regime.
On 12 June, 2019, QSD arrested a regime state TV correspondent in Quamishli in eastern al-Hasakeh countryside.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Syria (2000-) Prison Guards
NOTES: On 12 July, 2019, 1 journalist died as a result of torture in an unidentified regime prison after being detained for over 2 years. Unidentified location coded to Sidnaya Military Prison.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Syria (2000-) Prison Guards
NOTES: On 24 July 2019, the family of well-known freelance photographer was informed of the man's death inside the regiem's Sidnaya Military Prison.
On 25 July 2019, HTS fighters arrested a media activist in the town of Ibbin and took him to an unknown location.
On 24 August 2019, HTS forces arrested a journalist working with the Idleb Media Center from his home in Idleb city and took him to an unknown location.

On 25 August 2019, unidentified gunmen abducted a photographer from a pro-regime media agency in the town of Busra Esh-Sham and during the abduction they beat up another journalist who was trying to prevent them from taking the photographer.
On 11 September 2019, HTS forces arrested a media activists from the city of Idleb after he posted a video critical of HTS.
On 12 October 2019, HTS fighters abducted a media activist at the 'Deir Bullet' checkpoint in northern Idleb province for unknown reasons.
A few days before 12 October 2019, HTS fighters detained the supervisor of an HTS media channel somewhere in Idleb province over his support for the 'release the Knights of Aleppo' campaign.
On 28 October 2019, HTS arrested a civilian activist in Idleb city for unknown reasons.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Journalists (Syria); Health Workers (Syria); Kurdish Ethnic Group (Syria)
NOTES: On 29 October 2019, Sultan Murad Division fighters abducted a Kurdish woman in the Ras Al Ain area whom they claimed was a QSD fighter but was reportedly a journalist in a medical corp.
On 21 November 2019, HTS forces arrested a media activists at a checkpoint near the town of Rami. The activist had been critical of HTS and the Salvation Government.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Syria (2000-) Prison Guards
NOTES: As reported on 13 April 2020, a media activist from Aleppo province died under torture in an unidentified regime prison, coded to Sidnaya Military Prison. He was arrested on 7/3/2012 in Damascus. Some reports claim that he died in 2016.

On 10 June 2020, HTS members attacked a number of activists and journalists, physically assaulted them and confiscated their equipment near the M4 highway in Idleb as they were photographing the patrols. A Turkish patrol intervened dispersed the members.

On 13 August 2020, members of HTS physically assaulted and then detained a journalist of US nationality in Atmah in Idleb, after he had published a video interview with the wife of a British aid worker who was arrested by HTS on 11 August.]
On 2 October 2020, HTS detained a civilian who works in journalism photography at the HTS al Dahr checkpoint near Darkosh in Idleb.

On 5 October 2020, unidentified gunmen shot and killed 2 civilians on Da'el - Tafas road in Dar'a. One of the victims is a journalist who had accepted the reconciliation agreement with the regime, while both are former opposition fighters.
On 5 October 2020, HTS arrested a journalist from Ariha in Idleb city.
On 19 November 2020, QSD arrested a media activist, after they raided his house in Ar-Raqqa city.
On 12 December 2020, unknown gunmen riding a motorbike shot and killed a civilian journalist in Al Bab city in Aleppo countryside.
On 6 January 2021, unidentified gunmen shot and wounded a journalist and media activist on al Kornish street in Al Bab city of Aleppo. No fatalities were reported.
On 23 January 2021, QSD detained a journalist in Quamishli city in Al-Hasakeh countryside.
On 4 February 2021, QSD detained a media activist from Hajin hospital in Deir-ez-Zor during his coverage of a visit from the Global Coalition to a medical rehabilitation project.
