On 19 February 2021, unidentified gunmen opened fire on a media activist in the city of Afrin in Aleppo. He survived the assasination attempt. Neither injuries nor fatalities were reported.
On 25 February 2021, National Police Forces detained a media activist in Al Bab after having released him a few hours prior over his social media posts.
On 25 March 2021, a QSD military patrol stormed a media activist's house in Baghuz town in Deir-ez-Zor countryside, and detained him for criticizing living conditions.
On 5 April 2021, HTS have detained a media activist in Al Anadoul camp in Kafr Lusin area in Idleb countryside for unknown reasons.
On 7 April 2021, HTS detained a media activist from Daret Azza in Aleppo while travelling from Idleb city, where he worked, to Daret Azza in Aleppo.

On 24 April 2021, Asayish detained the director of the regime-affiliated radio and television center after storming his house in Quamishli city in al-Hasakeh. After mediation from Russian forces, Asayish released the director a few hours later.

On 24 April 2021, 2 unidentified gunmen on a motorcycle opened small arms fire at a media activist and his companion near Al Nahda project in Al Bab city in Aleppo, but missed their targets. Neither fatalities nor injuries were reported.

On 3 June 2021, suspected QSD gunmen physically assaulted and then kidnapped a prominent Assyrian journalist in Al-Malikeyyeh city in al-Hasakeh. After calls from local figures, the journalist was released the following day.
On 19 June 2021, QSD detained a journalist from his house in Ar-Raqqa city, for unknown reasons.
On 18 July 2021, QSD detained a journalist after storming his house in Rmelan in al-Hasakeh for unknown reasons.
On 13 August 2021, QSD detained a media activist and his brother, seized all his equipment from his house in Shafa in Deir-ez-Zor for unknown reasons.
On 4 September 2021, HTS detained 2 journalists displaced from Hama an IDP camp in Kafr Lusin area in Idleb for unknown reasons.
On 3 October 2021, QSD arrested the head of the media center and the Ar-Raqqa Civil Council in Ar-Raqqa city along with 3 other workers accused of dealing with the regime and JWS.
On 28 October 2021, JWS backed by the National police detained a media activist in Afrin city in Aleppo countryside, for criticizing the police on facebook for detaining two girls and their father.

On 9 November 2021, unknown gunmen attacked a TV channel crew in Quamishli city in Al Hasakeh countryside, while they were reporting on the explosion that had happened in the city, by beating them and confiscating their equipment.
On 7 December 2021, QSD launched a security operation and detained six journalists, after raiding Rudaw network office in Quamishli city in Al Hasakeh countryside for unknown reasons.

On 12 May 2020, two unidentified people wearing face-masks attacked and severely beaten a famous Tajik journalist in Dushanbe. According to the journalist the attack was preceded by numerous threats on a phone, related to journalist's criticism of the Tajik government in preventing coronavirus spread.

On 4 March 2021, two journalists of Radio's Liberty Tajik Service were attacked by a security personnel of a gas station in Dushanbe, while they were making a video-report on gas price increases. One of the journalists was pushed while another was kicked in the face reportedly for not having a written agreement to film from the management of the gas station. It has been reported that the city police has detained the man who attacked the journalists. The case is currently under investigation.

On 27 July 2010, a reporter for the Thai Rath newspaper and owner of the local newspaper Pathom Post was shot and killed at a local restaurant in Nakhon Pathom province. He had previously written articles investigating a corruption case involving a local politician.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: UDD: United Front for Democracy against Dictatorship; Journalists (Thailand)
NOTES: On 13 June 2011, a politically motivated shooting occurred at the house of a former red-shirt leader and well-known radio host in Chiang Mai Province coded at Chiang Mai city (MCM, CM). Police believe the attack was carried out by red-shirt figures. Four shots were fired into the house at the leader, but no one was injured.

A community radio host was fatally wounded in a drive-by shooting in Ubon Ratchathani Province on June 25. Police could not say clearly whether he was the latest victim of political violence in the lead-up to the July 3 election.
A reporter was shot dead at a rubber plantation. Police were investigating whether the killing was related to the insurgency.
Around 26 Jan 2019, in Bangkok, a Vietnamese blogger for Radio Free Asia (RFA) appeared to have gone missing after applying for asylum at the UN Refugee Agency.
Five journalists were attacked by an unidentified armed group during a press conference.
Togolese police attacked and confiscated the equipment of two journalists filming an anti-government march in the capital, Lome. The police were later disciplined.
Violence inflicted by security forces upon a journalist while covering a protest march organized by two opposition groups, the 'Collectif Sauvons le Togo' and 'Mouvement Arc-en ciel'
A trainee journalist at Focus Info suffered attacks by several policemen and gendarmerie who did not want him to take pictures and interview people. The policemen have since been arrested.
Military police officers beat and handcuffed a journalist while reporting on a land dispute in Lome.
On 15 April 2020, the soldiers of the special anti-coronavirus forces beat up and injured a journalist and a woman accused of violating the curfew in Lome city (Golfe, Maritime).

On 25 March 2020, in San Fernando, private security forces assaulted journalists at the San Fernando General Hospital after the journalists attempted to get footage of a viral tent over reports of a coronavirus case at the hospital.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: CNLT: National Council for Liberties in Tunisia; Women (Tunisia); Journalists (Tunisia)
NOTES: Sihem Bensedrine, journalist and founding member of the National Council for Liberties in Tunisia (CNLT), was assaulted as she left her home in downtown Tunis by three men in plainclothes, she believes were policemen, reported Human Rights Watch [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]
A French journalist is stabbed and beaten by attackers as he was abroad covering a story.
Police assault Russian journalists
A Radio Kalima reporter was attacked and beaten over the head by police officers while covering a demonstration on Bourguiba Avenue on 5 May. She had to be hospitalized.

A reporter was attacked in Tunis by police officers who pursued him into the headquarters of his newspaper, the French-language daily La Presse, after spotting him taking pictures of them dispersing protesters in the street outside.

SOURCE: Arabic Network for Human Rights Information
NOTES: Plainclothes police physically assaulted 15 local and international journalists while they were covering demonstrations in May. No location noted.
Journalists were attacked by the police while covering protests on Friday in Kasbah square.

SOURCE: Arabic Network for Human Rights Information
NOTES: Two journalists covering a protest at the Ministry of Higher Education were assaulted by plainclothes police officers. protesters were teachers from Manouba University in Tunis demanding the resumption of classes, which have been stopped all month due to protests against a law preventing women from attending school wearing the niqab.

Seven attacks on journalists by policeman occurred during a February 25 protest-turned-riot by members of the UGTT, who had assembled at the Ministry of the Interior to demonstrate against recent ransacking of UGTT offices. Police used tear gas to disperse the gathering and assaulted journalists covering the event.

ACTOR1: LPR: League for the Protection of the Revolution
NOTES: Tunisias Ministry of Interior has condemned an attack on journalists while they were covering a protest staged by the Committees for the Protection of the Revolution (CPR) outside the countries Parliament, Al-Jazeera reported on 27 June.

SOURCE: La Presse (Tunisia); Arabic Network for Human Rights Information
NOTES: A journalist at 'La Presse' newspaper- and his companions, were severely beaten with sticks and batons by a group of four people while they were leaving a hotel in Sulaiman district at Nabeul governorate.

SOURCE: Arabic Network for Human Rights Information
NOTES: Security personnel at National Security headquarters in Sidi Bouzid attacked a journalist while he was shooting an interview with a member of the Security Syndicate.

The National Union of Tunisian Journalists (SNJT) condemned an attack by police on a photojournalist while he was covering a protest held by youth groups outside the Ministry of Interior in the Tunisian capital.
Attacks were committed against a number of journalists who suffered verbal and physical violence by the police to prevent them from videotaping outside the Court of Kasserine on 27th May.

SOURCE: Arabic Network for Human Rights Information
NOTES: On Saturday August 30, some security personnel, who were at a security zone in Djerba, assaulted a blogger and her guard by beating, insulting and kicking them, while they were in her car nearby the security zone.
Police reportedly attacked journalists who gathered to report on a protest against alleged corruption in the energy sector in the centre of Tunis.

A journalist from Diwan FM who covered a sit-in in Sfax in support of a teacher that was accused of blasphemy was aggressed and injured by police forces. Another journalist who then came to the police station to support his colleague was similarly aggressed by police forces.

On 13 April 2021, police forces entered the headquarters of Agence Tunis Afrique Presse and violently attacked journalists in El Manar I (El Menzah, Tunis) under the order of the Tunisian Prime Minister to impose the appointment of a new director allegedly accused of corruption and support of media censorship under Ben Ali's regime.

On January 20, a group of people including an MP from HDP and journalists reportedly came under fire by the Turkish Army during operations in Cizre, Sirnak. 10 people were injured and two civilians were killed.

United Freedom Forces (BOG), a group formed by Turkish far-left groups fighting in Syria, attacked the office of the Yeni Safak Daily News editorial headquarters in Bayrampasa district of Istanbul by opening fire on the building and throwing Molotov cocktails, on February 11. There were no casualties.

United Freedom Forces (BOG), a group formed by Turkish far-left groups fighting in Syria, attacked the office of the Yeni Akit News offices in Kucukcekmece district of Istanbul by opening fire on the building and throwing Molotov cocktails, on February 11. Several cars outside the building was also damaged. There were no casualties.

On February 21 2016, three journalists working for Anadolu Agency were kidnapped by PKK members in Nusaybin district of Mardin. PKK released the journalists on the same day to HDP members in the same area.
On April 10, a Syrian journalist was shot and later died in the hospital by Islamic State militants in Gaziantep town.

Can Dundar, the Turkish journalist standing trial on the charges of revealing state secrets, escaped an assassination attempt when an attacker fired a series of shots aimed at him while he was waiting for his court verdict outside the court in Sisli, Istanbul. One reporter was mildly injured from ricocheting bullets.

A Syrian journalist was severely wounded when he was shot in the head by two men on a motorcycle multiple times while he was inside his car late on the 12th of June. The attack took place inside the city of Sanliurfa. IS later claimed the attack.

There have been fights after a soccer game between different fan groups on 16/01/2017, which the police tried to control. Some Journalists have filmed this incident and claimed that the Police have attacked them and forced them to delete the filmed material.

A journalist, who has been detained in Diyarbakir on 17/02/2017, claims to be beaten up by the Police Forces of Turkey during his detainment. He had bruises on his body. Another man detained on the same day also claimed to have been beaten.

SOURCE: Daily Sabah; AFP; CNN; Cumhuriyet; Hurriyet Daily
NOTES: On October 2, a Saudi columnist known for his critical views of the Saudi regime, Jamal Khashoggi, disappeared after entering the Saudi consulate in the Besiktas area of Istanbul. Turkish sources later reported that he was tortured and killed inside the consulate and that audio evidence exists of the event, although this has not been made public. Turkish media has also reported on an alleged 'hit squad' made up of members of different branches of the Saudi military and intelligence service reported on a flight manifesto and seen on public video coming into Turkey. On October 16, Turkish police searched the Saudi consulate and allegedly found evidence showing that Khashoggi was killed inside, although it is not clear what this evidence was since it was not made public. On Oct 21, Saudi Arabia admitted that Khashoggi was killed in the Saudi consulate after a scuffle with Saudi personnel who were trying to bring him back to Saudi Arabia, however the Saudi Crown is distancing itself from the incident. 18 people have allegedly been arrested as suspects. On Oct 25 Saudi Arabia's public prosecutor was quoted in state media as saying Khashoggi's murder was 'premeditated'. The narratives of his death remain inconsistent and it is unknown where his body is.
As reported on March 19, 14 people including HDP members and journalists that were detained on March 14 were subjected to torture and mistreatment under detention in Mersin province.

On March 22, Police forces were reported to have beaten up two journalists after they were stopped and taken to the Mardin Police Headquarters in Mardin city where they objected to the seizure of their cameras by the police forces.

As reported on May 16, a woman journalist who was detained during the hunger strike protests in Istanbul city claimed to have been severely beaten up by the Police forces under detention along with the other detained women.

From May 10 to May 26, five journalists were reported to be attacked in different parts of Turkey, possibly due to the political position of the journals they work at and/or their articles interpreted to be opponent. One of the journalists was from Egemen newspaper and he was shot in the leg by unknown attackers in Seyhan, Adana city, on May 24. He later stated that he had been receiving death threat calls over the last few days.

On May 28, one person was reported to be beaten up by the police forces who took him to the police booth in Gayrettepe metro station in Sisli, Istanbul reportedly after the policemen realized that he was distributing a newspaper (Yeni Yasam), that is perceived to be of opposition.

As reported on August 29th, a journalist was subjected to physical violence by police and then taken into custody after he was reporting from the crime scene of a traffic accident in Kucukcekmece district of Istanbul.

On November 16, 2 journalists who were detained by the Police forces were subject to physical violence at the police station where they were kept under custody in Izmir province. The detainees were phsyically assaulted as they were handcuffed and forced to strip search.
On November 20 2019, a Turkish journalist was attacked by an unidentified man with a baseball bat outside his home in Ankara's Dikmen district. He was taken to the hospital.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Turkey (2016-) Prison Guards
NOTES: On March 6, prison guards physically assaulted an arrested journalist upon his arrival at Silivri prison in Silivri, Istanbul. No other information regarding the details of the attack was provided.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Turkey (2016-) Prison Guards
NOTES: On March 12, 2020, prison guards physically assaulted a group of prisoners in Manisa T Type prison, Manisa for refusing to stand up during a routine count, which allegedly caused fractures in cheekbone and ribs of one prisoner and bruises on various parts of several other prisoners' bodies.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Turkey (2016-) Prison Guards
NOTES: As reported on March 13, 2020, prison guards physically assaulted prisoners in Delice prison in Delice, Kirikkale. Following the incident, 85 prisoners including the victims of the attack were transferred to other prisons. No other information regarding the incident was reported.

On 12 August 2020, a 70-year-old woman journalist was physically assaulted by police officer at the back-to-school flea market near Gulistan shopping center of Ashgabat city, after she took pictures on her camera for a photo story. Policemen claimed that taking photos were forbidden in that space.
LRA rebels raided a radio relay station in northern Uganda cutting off communications between Gulu town and areas in the northwest
LRA rebels raided a church-run radio station and burnt it down - 1 civilian was killed
Unidentified men attack, rape and kill local journalist
Police assault civilian journalists
Unidentified group attacks journalist, attempts to kidnap him. The attackers were suspected soldiers

a news presenter on Prime Radio, a Seventh Day Adventist station in the southeastern district of Mukono, was beaten to death by unidentified assailants using metal bars as he walked to work on 13 September.
Two radio journalists were assaulted by NRM MP, Sauda Namagwa, in Masaka when attempting to get information about the electoral contest in the region.
Soldiers shot freelance journalist Julius Odeke near Bugusege in Eastern Uganda while covering electoral violence in the East of the country.

Four journalists and voters were attacked by stick-wielding Kiboko Squad at the Super FM radio station in Rubaga, Kampala. Police intervened to assist them. Party affiliation of attackers not mentioned.

Stick-wielding thugs with links to the Kampala mayoral candidate for the ruling National Resistance Movement (NRM) party, Peter Ssematimba, assaulted six journalists at the Kakeeka polling station, in Rubaga Parish, in Kampalas Lubaga division. There are indications that the hooligans formulated a plan to beat up journalists since they called media houses to say that Ssematimba was going to vote at the Kakeeka polling station at 10:00 a.m. and they requested a media presence.

Two journalists reported injured in demonstration organized by opposition political parties in Jinja town, Eastern Uganda. Journalists who were at the scenereported that anti-riot police were targeting television camera persons and photojournalists who were in front of the demonstrators.
Freelance journalist assaulted by NRM Kanungu Town Councillor, Emmy Magezi Byarugaba, while covering his trial for assault charges.
A reporter covering the clashes which broke out at Mutendwe campus was arrested and assaulted by police officers.
WBS TV cameraman Francis Mukasa was beaten at Makindye Ssabagabo court while covering protests following the arrest of the Kampala mayor-elect Ssalongo Erias Lukwago.

A Radio One journalist, was seriously roughed up by military personnel at Wampeewo, from where he was relaying live scenes of gunfire. Muyinda was properly identified as a journalist because he was in his radio station jacket.
Reports that Radio Simba journalist was targeted by riot police while covering the dispersal of protesters in Lugogo.
Unidentified assailants attacked New Vision journalist Goodluck Musinguizi and set fire to his home in Rushaki war, Kabale.
At least two journalists reported being harassed and targeted by police while covering the dispersal of crowds in Constitution Square.
At least 10 Ugandan and foreign journalists were physically attacked by soldiers while covering opposition leader Kizza Besigyes return to Uganda from Kenya.

At least ten journalists reported being harassed, targeted and assaulted by members of the police and security forces while trying to cover the return of opposition leader, Kizza Besigye. Several reported showing their press identification and being assaulted anyway.
Security forces abduct a journalist and hold him for two weeks on suspicion of terrorism.

The editor of Rwandas Inyenyeri news, Charles Ingabire, who had sought refuge in Uganda for political reasons, has been shot dead at a Kampala pub. It is unclear if the murder was political or random.
Journalist beaten by police for photographing scuffle between officers and residents
Armed men attack journalist and his family as they drove through Kampala
Police shoot tear gas cannister at journalist covering A4C event

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: A4C: Activists for Change Group; Journalists (Uganda)
NOTES: Police attack A4C activists, journalists and bystanders at peaceful gathering
Police assault journalists covering Besigyes arrest
Police assault journalists covering Besigyes trial; take journalists to central police station, detain and beat them
Police assault journalist covering student book launch
Police arrest and mistreat journalist
Police assault journalist covering boda-boda driver protest

SOURCE: Human Rights Network for Journalists Uganda
NOTES: Police assault journalists covering a story in Kampala
Police attack journalists covering arrest of Besigye at Kampala Central Police Station
Police stop, arrest, beat and torture a journalist for the Associated Press.
A woman was 'paraded' before local media, outed as a transsexual, beaten, undressed and arrested' by police forces.
A journalist alleges that he was badly beaten multiple times by policemen as he was covering local elections
The SPLA is suspected of taking hostage several local leaders and journalists in Wano Village, Moyo district during a national census exercise .
A journalist covering a demonstration by an activist youth group - National Association of the Unemployed - in Kampala is detained and severely beaten into a coma by the police.

A group of about 30 men with clubs attack two journalists leaving both of them hospitalised. The journalists had recently published pieces alleging that the Tooro Royal family had been acquiring land illegally. The police reportedly refused to investigate the assault.
UPDF attacked fishermen in Kalangala; a journalist tried to take photo. He was then attacked by the UPDF.
At least three journalists were arrested by police forces at Kira road police station for reporting on FDCs Ssemujjus arrest. Police reportedly used violence on journalists.
A journalist was assaulted and sustained injuries while covering a story in which a police officer was implicated in vote rigging prior the NRM party elections.
NRM parliamentary aspirant Eddy Ssansa allegedly assaulted a female journalist at Masaka police station on 28 October

A journalist was reportedly shot in the head while covering an incident of vote rigging during NRM party elections at Bulera police station in the Mityana district. Two unidentified men have so far been arrested and detained. The scuffle ensued when an unidentified man turned up at a polling station near the police with ballot papers, and could not explain where he got them. The local people became hostile and wanted to lynch him, but he managed to escape and hid inside the police station. His car was broken into, and the ballot papers were scattered by angry locals.

SOURCE: Human Rights Network for Journalists Uganda
NOTES: 2 journalists were shot in the head by police while covering the arrest of Capital Citys Lord Mayor, Erias Lukwago. The two journalists are alive but in critical condition.

Ali Lubuuka Golooba, a journalist with Buddu FM in Masaka is nursing injuries he sustained in an attack by suspected body guards of Muhammad Muyanja Mbabaali, the Bukoto South NRM parliamentary candidate in Lwengo district.
A reporter was reportedly assaulted by a Ugandan police officer in Kampala while covering a demonstration by a group of unemployed youth.
A journalist was severely beaten by police while covering a procession by the Unemployed Youths of Uganda (UAU), to the police headquarters in Naguru.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Uganda (1986-) Special Forces Command
NOTES: Two Democratic Party supporters were shot at by Special Forces Command (SFC) soldiers in Entebbe Municipality as they protected a journalist who was being attacked by supporters of the ruling party at a polling station.
Police and soldiers allegedly beat people, including journalists, in Kampala, ahead of the inauguration of President Museveni the following day.

SOURCE: Human Rights Network for Journalists Uganda
NOTES: Two journalists in Iganga district were allegedly battered by the head of the security team of the Busoga Kingdom leader while covering the launch of the inter-county soccer tournament, sustaining head and chest injuries. Iganga District Police Commander intervened to restrain the soldier from doing more harm to the journalists.
A Burundian journalist exiled in Uganda was allegedly stabbed by four unidentified attackers, including two suspected fellow Burundians, in Kampala, sustaining severe injuries.
A Ugandan journalist who had spoken out about the arrest of Ugandan activist Stella Nyanzi, was abducted, driven around, and dumped on the road.
Police officers at Katwe Police Station have stoned five journalists who were covering staff quarters that had caught fire at the police station.

Police officers chased and whipped several journalists who were covering the trial of former Buyende DPC Muhammad Kirumira in Kololo, Kampala. Journalists who were covering the event were waiting for them at the location when they were assaulted by police, who beat and punched them, forcing them to flee. These reports of violence are denied by the police.

SOURCE: Human Rights Network for Journalists Uganda
NOTES: During the week of 11 July, journalists covering an NRM meeting in Apac began to interview UPC youths as well. The NRM youths grew angry and assaulted the journalists.
On 13 Augst, the police arrested journalists at the Pacific Hotel in Arua after riots erupted in the area. They were severely beaten and their equipment was confiscated.
On 20 August, observer journalists were arrested as they returned to their offices, in Mulago, Kampala. They were beaten and the soldiers used pliers to torture them.
On August 31st, and amidst riots in Kampala, a journalist with the NBS television station - Joshua Mujunga - was beaten by security forces.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Police Forces of Uganda (1986-); Journalists (Uganda); Women (Uganda)
NOTES: On Feb 24th, two soldiers - acting in their capacity as bodyguards for retired Major General Matayo Kyaligonza (the current Ugandan ambassador to Burundi)- were filmed assaulting a traffic police officer (recorded as a civilian, with police as assoc actor2) after she had summoned the vehicle over a traffic offence. The incident - which has sparked national outrage, took place in Seeta (Mukono). A journalist filiming the incident also alleged that the soldiers assaulted him. The two soldiers have been arrested, and the retired Major General called in for questioning over his alleged involvement in the assault.

On September 15th, a South Sudanese journalist was abducted in Kampala, and beaten by four men (two of who the reporter said appeared to be Ugandan, and two South Sudanese). The journalist escaped during the attack.

SOURCE: Weekly Observer; Daily Monitor (Uganda); URN (Uganda); Chimp Reports
NOTES: On October 25th, 15 journalists covering a student press conference (which was addressing the unrest at Mekerere University over the previous three days) were beaten and had tear gas fired upon them by police forces at Makerere University (Kampala).
On October 29th, police fired tear gas against journalists covering protests at Markerere University (Kampala), and arrested three.

On October 30th, police fired tear gas inside a student dormitory in Makerere neighbourhood (Kampala), after its residents began whistling at them. The police then fired at journalists covering the events.

On 19 March 2020, unspecified security forces (presumed to be police) beat a journalist who was taking photos of police shutting down a bar at an unspecified area of Kitgum district, under coronavirus lockdown measures.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Uganda (1986-) Local Defense Unit
NOTES: On 31 March 2020, LDU paramilitaries beat a journalist and the driver of the boda boda he was travelling with in Makindye (Kampala), and insisted they be paid a bribe to release them. The attack was ostensibly related to coronavirus enforcement measures.

On 1 April 2020, police and UPDF attacked and beat an on-duty journalist in Ntungamo (Ntungamo district) after he was taking photos of coronavirus lockdown measures. The security forces then stole his camera.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Uganda (1986-) Local Defense Unit
NOTES: On 2 April 2020, LDU paramilitaries beat a journalist in or near Nakisunga (Mukono district), for violating the coronavirus curfew. The journalist entered a coma for ten hours but was revived; an LDU officer has been arrested.
On 2 April 2020, a journalist was 'severely beaten' by unspecified security forces (presumed to be police) in Mukono (Mukono district), whilst covering coronavirus curfew measures.
On 20 May 2020, police attacked four journalists in Fort Portal (Kabarole district), ostensibly for breaching coronavirus lockdown measures.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: NUP: National Unity Platform; FDC: Forum for Democratic Change; Journalists (Uganda)
NOTES: On 3 November 2020, police and UPDF intercepted Bobi Wine MP in Kampala shortly after he filed his nomination papers. The Presidential aspirant stated he was tortured for several hours in a police van before being released. The FDC contender was also detained by authorities, and may have been abused in custody whilst in route to submit his nomination papers. A journalist covering the FDC contender was also attacked by police.
On 3 November 2020, journalists covering the nomination of Bobi Wine MP were attacked with pepper spray by police in the Nakawa area of Kampala.
On 5 November 2020, a freelance journalist was shot in the face with a rubber bullet by police as he filmed Bobi Wine MP in Kamwokya (Kampala).
On 18 November 2020, police beat journalists at an NUP-rally at Luuka town (Luuka district), whilst firing tear gas at NUP supporters and arresting Bobi Wine MP.

On 6 December 2020, police blocked NUP candidate Bobi Wine (the alias of Ssentamu Robert Kyagulanyi) from holding a campaign rally in Jinja (Jinja Municipality, Jinja). Police dispersed supporters with teargas, also leaving a journalist injured.

On 11 December 2020, police attacked and injured at least 2 journalists who covered the police blocking of NUP candidate Bobi Wine (the alias of Ssentamu Robert Kyagulanyi) from passing through Alebtong and Lira district. 13 people were also arrested for obstructing police from executing their duties.

On 15 December 2020, police forces detained and beat up a journalist for taking photos at a rally of Bobi Wine (the alias of Ssentamu Robert Kyagulanyi) in Kampala (Kampala Capital City, Kampala). They later took his equipment.

On 27 December 2020, police clashed with NUP supporters during an election rally near Lwengo (Bukoto, Lwengo) leaving a journalist covering the rally hospitalised after being injured by a teargas canister as well as two cameramen. NUP candidate Bobi Wine (the alias of Ssentamu Robert Kyagulanyi) also said that a member of his security team was killed by a police vehicle when he was trying to help the journalist.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: FDC: Forum for Democratic Change; Journalists (Uganda)
NOTES: On 1 January 2021, journalists covering the campaign of the FDC presidential candidate in Nebbi, (Nebbi, Nebbi district), were beaten by police forces and forced to delete their media material.

On 6 January 2021, a journalist was detained by security forces and tortured for two weeks in Manafwa prison (Bugisa, Manafwa). He was filming NUP candidate Bobi Wine's campaign tour in northern Uganda and had recorded the police interacting with NUP supporters.

Around 13 January 2021 (as reported), a journalist was arrested and beaten by the army in Nebbi (Nebbi Municipality, Nebbi). He was covering a raid by the army at the home of FDC flagbearer for Nebbi Municipality seat.

On 25 January 2021, soldiers of Uganda People's Defence Forces (UPDF) and other security operatives attacked a journalist during elections in Banga-Nakiwogo polling station in Entebbe (Entebbe Municipality, Wakiso). The forces grabbed voter registers from a number of polling agents and took over management of the mayoral elections. No fatalities/injuries reported.
On 6 February 2021, a journalist was reportedly attacked and killed by unidentified men in Kanyanya (Kampala Capital District, Kampala).

SOURCE: Daily Express (Uganda); All Africa; Vanguard Africa
NOTES: On 7 February 2021, unidentified men attacked, tortured and killed a journalist in Kanyanya (Kampala Capital City, Kampala). He reportedly covered the NUP court filing, challenging the claimed election victory of President Museveni.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Uganda (1986-) Military Police
NOTES: On 17 February 2021, military police attacked and injured at least 10 journalists when trying to disperse them from covering a National Unity Platform (NUP) event in Kololo (Kampala Capital City, Kampala). The NUP officials led by party President Robert Kyagulanyi went to the UN offices to hand over a petition against alleged human rights violations in the wake of December elections. The soldiers reportedly also attacked and damaged the vehicle of the Makindye East MP elect. 6 soldiers were handed prison sentences.
On 23 April 2021, security operatives (UPDF unit) beat up an NTV journalist in Mityana town (Central).

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Uganda (1986-) Local Defense Unit
NOTES: On 30 April 2021, government military (Local Defense Unit) shot and killed a senior journalist at Bugembejembe village in Wakiso district (Busiro, Central).
On 13 May 2021, police officers beat and injured a journalist who was investigating a cattle theft in a police station in Kiboga (Central). No fatalities reported.
On 4 July 2021, police officers attacked and wounded a journalist for allegedly violating the curfew rules in Busiu (Bungokho, Mbale).
On 29 July 2021, police forces assaulted and wounded a journalist, accused of taking picture of security officers, near a refugee camp in Adjumani district (Northern). No fatalities were reported.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Ukraine (2014-2019) ARMA: National Agency for Identifying, Tracing and Managing Assets Obtained through Corruption and Other Crimes
NOTES: On 8 February 2018, a journalist was injured after gas was dispersed in the Vesti office as the National Agency for Identifying, Tracing and Managing Assets Obtained through Corruption and Other Crimes took control of the editorial offices of the Vesti newspaper in Kiev. This was done under criminal proceedings against the former minister for taxes and levies, who is accused of corruption.
On 21 March 2018, an Azerbaijani journalist was attacked at his residence in Kiev by unknown persons, which resulted in several injuries.

On 26 March 2018, four unidentified individuals, presumably belonging to the far right groups, attacked a journalist Ilya Romanenko in Kiev - Podilskyi. They sprayed pepper spray into his face and beat him. The victim believes, that the reason behind the attack was his participation in the discussion about the problem of the spread of ultra-right movements in Ukraine, that had been held earlier that day.

On 14 April 2018, unknown persons opened fire upon a car with journalists of the Slidstvo.info Maksym Opanasenko and Kirill Shapar in Kiev - Holosiivskyi. The incident occurred while the crew was filming the story about one of the Ukrainian oligarchs.

Around 25 May 2018 (as reported), two unidentified assailants knocked off the feet and repeatedly kicked the editor of the website devoted to revealing corruption of the local authorities, in Dnipro, Ukraine.
On 8 June 2018, three unidentified perpetrators knocked of the feet and beat a journalist Kostyantyn Hrechanyy in Odessa, Ukraine.

On 18 June 2018, two men beat up the editor-in-chief of 'MOST' and the coordinator of 'UA Centre' Serhiy Nikitenko in Kherson. The journalist claims the incident is related to his professional activity.

On 26 June 2018, three unidentified individuals sprayed pepper gas at, beat and stole belongings of the chief editor of an online media website in Zatoka, Odessa. No report on the motives of the attack.

On 10 July 2018, the wife of Opposition Bloc councillor Oleksandr Vlasov assaulted a female journalist Yevheniya Virlich, who was investigating Vlasov's illegal family business, inside the Kherson city council. The journalist was admitted to a hospital with bruises and concussion.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Ukraine (2014-2019) Municipal Guard
NOTES: On 16 July 2018, two members of the local municipal guard police forces pepper sprayed and beat three journalists in Odessa.

On 2 August 2018, in an apparent planned attack, a lorry deliberately crashed into a car occupied by two activists, including a journalist and leader of the People's Movement of Ukraine and an anti-corruption activist, in Odessa. The lorry driver escaped with an accomplice on a motorbike waiting nearby. No injuries were reported.
On 6 August 2018, members of C14 splashed with brilliant green antiseptic the face of a pro-Kremlin journalist, who is accused of high treason, as he was leaving a court in Zhytomyr.

ACTOR1: NAF: United Armed Forces of Novorossiya
NOTES: On 3rd September, in Donetsk, a military man, presumably NAF soldier assaulted Russian journalist during live broadcast. Journalist sustained minor injures.

On 28 September 2018, in Kyiv, around 30 young men, most of whom had Sich insignia on their clothes, present in the courtroom during the trial of a journalist being accused of treason. The SMM heard the young men verbally insulting the journalist and his defence team and saw small objects being thrown at them. Later, ten police officers in riot gear entered the courtroom, at which point the disruptions ceased.

On Nov. 29 2018, after the arrest of the Ukrainian blogger Oleksandr Baraboshko in Kiev, Ukraine, members of the military prosecutor's office inflicted light bodily injuries on him and tried to obtain evidence by force.

On Dec. 12 2018, in Kryvyi Rih, a group of people beat journalist Vitaliy Kovalenko with metal pipes and stole the documents and materials of his journalistic investigation into the Southern reservoir.
On Jan. 4 2019, a church guard refused to let in and beat journalists who came to film a meeting of priests of the Orthodox Church of the Moscow Patriarchate in Vinnytsia, Ukraine.
On Jan. 24 2019, unidentified persons beat a film crew of the Stop Corruption investigative project, damaged their car with an axe and stole their belongings in Holosiivskyi district of Kiev.
On Feb. 8 2019, a man fired a hunting rifle at windows of a radio station in Kalush, Ivano-Frankivsk. During his arrest, he wounded a police officer with a knife.

On 22 February, an unidentified individual threw two bottles with incendiary mixture in the editorial office of a local online magazine in Rivne. The journalists were inside, called the firefighters and tried to put out the fire. No injuries were reported.

On 6 March, a group of people hit two journalists and damaged their equipment after they came to a settlement council in Chabany, Kiev. The journalists identified two deputy village heads and representatives of a local NGO connected to the village head as attackers.

On 1 May, unidentified individuals broke into a house of a local journalist, poured incendiary mixture and set it to fire in Novovolynsk, Volyn. The journalist managed to put out the fire, no injuries were reported. [size=no report]

SOURCE: Kharkiv Human Rights Protection Group; Twitter; Liveuamap; Hromadske Radio
NOTES: On 4 May, in an apparent premeditated attack, an investigative journalist was beaten by unidentified individuals causing him to go into a coma in Cherkasy. The journalist died in hospital on 20 June.

On 13 June, a supporter of the MP candidate Borys Pryhodko (Tribuna/l party), beat two journalists of Stop Corruption NGO in Pryluky. The journalists tried to get into the election campaigning event and wanted to check their information on vote-buying.

SOURCE: Segodnya; Novoye Vremya Ukraine; Focus; Stop Corruption
NOTES: On 21 July, a journalist died in Slavutych, Kiev, after three unidentified individuals beat him and cut his throat.

On 31 July 2019, an unidentified individual severely beat an editor-in-chief of a local news media in Vinnytsia over his articles on the Party of Shariy. Previously, the journalist received threats from Party of Shariy supporters.

SOURCE: Sputnik News Service; LIGA.net; Novoye Vremya Ukraine
NOTES: On 1 August, unidentified people attacked a camera crew of journalists investigating falsifications during the parliamentary elections in Pokrovsk, Donetsk. One of the journalists was hospitalised with concussion, property of the journalists was damaged. One of the attackers is a political strategist of the mayor of the city and a parliamentary candidate from the Opposition Bloc who won the elections in this district.

SOURCE: Focus; Stop Corruption; Novoye Vremya Ukraine; LIGA.net; Segodnya; Reporter-ua; Sputnik News Service
NOTES: On 28 August, a group of guards and workers of a woodworking plant, gathered around 112 Channel journalists who were filming a story about timber theft and illegal logging in Zolochiv, Kharkiv. The guards blocked the way for the journalists, tried to grab their equipment, damaged their car and beat at least one journalist. The police detained 30 people. [size=at least 30]
On 30 August, unidentified people attacked and beat a journalist in Chernihiv who was accusing deputies of the regional council of corruption and high treason. The journalist suffered a concussion.
On 31 August, a journalist was beaten by unidentified attackers in Vinnytsia for his articles about Parliamentary candidate Anatoliy Shariy.

SOURCE: Stop Corruption; Focus; Novoye Vremya Ukraine; LIGA.net
NOTES: On 30 November, unidentified individuals beat and sprayed unknown substance in the face of a local journalist near his house in Mykolaiv. The journalist was hospitalised with damage to his eyes, mouth and trachea.
On 1 December, an unidentified individual sprayed with pepper spray and beat a local journalist near his block of flats in Odessa. The same journalist was shot at in 2012 and abducted in 2014.
On 20 April 2020, two unidentified individuals attacked and beat a local journalist in Kharkiv. Exact motive of the attackers is unknown.

On 14 October 2020, unidentified individuals tried to run over, severely beat and stole the belongings of a journalist team from Stop Corruption in the area of Synelnykove, Dnipropetrovsk. The victims claim that the attackers are affiliated with a deputy of the local regional council.

SOURCE: 24 Channel; Sputnik News Service; Novoye Vremya Ukraine
NOTES: On 17 October 2020, three unidentified individuals attacked and severely beat an editor-in-chief of Alternatyva.org news portal in Velykodolynske, Odessa. The victim accused the Opposition Platform - For Life party.
On 30 October 2020, an unidentified individual attacked with a knife or a piece of glass a journalist near his house in Kiev and cut his face.
On 3 November 2020, unidentified individuals attacked and severely beat a journalist, who carried out anti-corruption investigations, near his house in Volnovakha, Donetsk.
On 10 February 2021, unidentified people attacked a civil society activist and journalist in Pyriatyn, Poltava.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Russia (2000-) Federal Security Service
NOTES: On 10 March 2021, Russian Federal Security Service detained a Ukrainian journalist in Simferopol, Crimea, and accused him of 'preparing sabotage, weapons possession and espionage'. They tortured him by means of electric shocks and suffocation with a plastic bag in order to obtain the evidence necessary for the investigation.
On 24 March 2021, an unidentified person attacked a journalist of Stop Corruption in Kharkiv.
On 14 May 2021, security guards of the Acting Mayor of Kharkiv City Council attacked a journalist, when he tried to ask a question about the memorialization of Gennady Kernes, the previous Mayor.
On 3 November 2021, an unidentified man attacked and doused an investigative journalist with an unknown substance in Khmelnytskyi.

On Jan. 17, 2019: Journalist Mirjana Mircevska from Kanal 5 TV was dragged and pushed by guards of the security agency Nikob while she was trying to interview a person who participated in a traditional celebration of Epiphany in Skopje.The journalist was hospitalized with a neck and hand injuries.

On 17 September 2020, two unidentified individuals severely beat an activist and blogger, who became famous for recording and sharing with the public conversations of government officials, near his home in Skopje. The victim was hospitalised in critical condition.

Several foreign and Egyptian journalists covering the parliamentary elections in Egypt were beaten, roughed up or intimidated on Wednesday. Some were attacked by unidentified men and women in civilian clothes, an Egyptian cameraman was seen being beaten by police wielding metal bars.

Several foreign and Egyptian journalists covering the parliamentary elections in Egypt were beaten, roughed up or intimidated on Wednesday. Some were attacked by unidentified men and women in civilian clothes, an Egyptian cameraman was seen being beaten by police wielding metal bars.

Several foreign and Egyptian journalists covering the parliamentary elections in Egypt were beaten, roughed up or intimidated on Wednesday. Some were attacked by unidentified men and women in civilian clothes, an Egyptian cameraman was seen being beaten by police wielding metal bars.

On Jan 23, in Garden City, Cairo, two supporters of NFF Parliamentary candidate Hussein Abu Gad assaulted Rania Fazza, Youm7 journalist, while she was covering parliamentary elections following the death of a deputy.

An AP photographer was hit in the face by a stone thrown by a police officer while he was covering protests in Cairo. He was also allegedly beaten by the officer. A guardian reporter was also beaten after being detained while covering the protests. 5 other journalists with local organizations were 'roughed up' by police.
An Al-Jazeera correspondent, Ahmad Mansur, was assaulted by plain clothes security personnel. The location of the event was not reported.
An Egyptian journalist is shot while covering uprisings, dying a week later.
A journalist from New Zealand is assaulted while covering Egyptian protests.
A Swedish reporter is attacked by a group of violent protesters with knives, then arrested by police forces. Two Russian journalists for VGTRK television were also attacked.
Two journalists for Al Jazeera are attacked by 'thugs'. A journalist for Al-Arabiya also suffered a concussion.
A Greek journalist working for Khaterimini has been injured during clashes.
A journalist for Al-Arabiya suffers a concussion.
A group of men described as 'plainclothes police' attacked the HQ of the independent daily Al-Shorouk in Cairo. Two employees were injured and the HQ was evacuated.

Egyptian security forces again stormed Al Jazeeras offices, confining its journalists to one room and confiscating equipment. The security personnel allegedly also roughed up their staff and took their identity papers.

SOURCE: Reporters Sans Frontieres; Uncut Index on Censorship
NOTES: Journalists were allegedly beaten by security forces in Cairo and other cities as demonstrators protested to demand a civilian government across Egypt. At least one in Cairo was allegedly detained and beaten by personnel from the interior ministry.

SOURCE: Uncut Index on Censorship; Reporters Sans Frontieres
NOTES: Journalists were allegedly beaten by security forces in Cairo and other cities as demonstrators protested to demand a civilian government across Egypt. At least one in Cairo was allegedly detained and beaten by personnel from the interior ministry.
An Al-Ahram reporter was allegedly beaten and detained by Egyptian security forces while covering protests in downtown Cairo.

SOURCE: Youm7; Arabic Network for Human Rights Information
NOTES: On 20 November 2011, journalists were assaulted in Alexandria during ongoing protests to demand civilian rule. At least one was detained an beaten by security forces. This occurred when thousands of people marched after a funeral in the morning for a man killed by security forces.
An American journalist claims to have been sexually assaulted at the hands of police during rioting.
Two female journalists, one American, one French, were beaten and sexually harassed by police officers and other unidentified assailants ('thugs') while they were covering clashes in Tahrir Square.
A French journalist claims to have been sexually assaulted by protesters while covering the rioting.
23 reporters subject to violence, one was shot in the back but survived
Sawfat Hegazy, the pro-Muslim Brotherhood preacher who gave the sermon at Friday's gathering in Tahrir Square, physically and verbally attacked two photographers covering the day's events.
Crowds prevented a newspaper editors entrance into the Media Production City and then proceeded to assault both Mr. Khaleds person and property
an experienced newspaper reporter, died in hospital after being hit in the head by a rubber bullet fired by supporters of Mohamed Morsi

SOURCE: Egypt State Information Service; Kuwait News Agency
NOTES: Dozens of gunmen attacked Al-Wafd Party headquarters as well as the party newspapers offices, throwing flares that set fire to the building as well as smashing the windshields of several parked cars and injuring Al-Wafd members
Mohamed El-Meshtawi, editor of Masryoon newspaper was attacked by a group of unknown armed men with bladed weapons.

The Press Syndicate issued a statement on Sunday condemning the attack on syndicate president Mamdouh Al-Wali by journalists protesting outside the syndicate building. The attack took place on Friday as Al-Wali attempted to enter the syndicate.
Central security recruits protesting in Tanta forced an Al-Jazeera television team out of the strike, accusing the Qatari-owned channel of defaming the image of the interior ministry.

An alleged assault against journalists occurred Saturday evening outside the Brotherhoods headquarters where journalists were covering a meeting.The journalists say that after activists sprayed anti-Brotherhood graffiti on the ground outside the headquarters, the Brotherhood guards attacked with sticks and chains.

Together with Al-Masry, activist Ranwa Youssef was arrested and sexually harassed inside a police station. Photographer Sameh Mashali, a young activist known for documenting clashes, was arrested as well in Alexandria, on the same day but in a different protest. He was beaten first. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

Journalists covering the clashes were themselves attacked by demonstrators and at least five were injured. Both Muslim Brotherhood supporters and members of the anti-Morsi 'Black Bloc' counter-demonstration attacked journalists.

Similar events occurred in Alexandria, where at least six journalists were attacked. In most cases, they were attacked while filming. Equipment and recordings were destroyed, leaving no doubt about the targeted na-ture of the attacks.
Two photographers have reported being assaulted during the violence at the Rabaa Al-Adaweya sit-in
Three journalists, including a cameraman for British broadcaster Sky News and a Dubai-based newspaper reporter, were killed and several were injured in the violence that erupted in Egypt
Al-Ahrams correspondent in Beheira was killed at a checkpoint in Damanhaour.
Unidentified gunmen attacked North Sinai Radio station and intelligence building in Rafah but no causalities were reported.
A journalist was assaulted and tortured by police in Al Minya
Security forces attacked journalists in Alexandria.
The radio building came under fire from unidentified gunmen several times on Sunday [10 November] without leaving casualties.

The Journalists union strongly condemned violations against journalists and media workers covering demonstrations (Tuesday), which amounted to prevent journalists from working and assault, and breaking down their equipment and taking it in addition to the detention of a number of journalists from the site of events and abuse beatings and insults.

Two photojournalists were arrested by the military police from Cairo on Friday while covering a Muslim Brotherhood protest in Helmeyet Al-Zaitoun District. The journalist said that a military officer dragged him inside the Officers Club and assaulted him.
While covering a Muslim Brotherhood march in Maadi, a journalist was hit with birdshot in the head and chest.

A journalist was shot dead while working for Qatar-based satellite broadcaster Al-Jazeera whilst covering the third anniversary clashes. Another photojournalist working for the center-right Wafd party newspaper, was shot in the face and underwent surgery to rebuild his mouth.

The Association for Freedom of Thought and Expression (AFTE) said it spotted 36 violation cases, which range from banning journalists and breaking their equipments or seizing it to arresting and assaulting them at coverage of clashes on Saturday.
Policemen attacked a CBC Extra channel reporter while covering the news on bomb blasts on Giza Bridge on Friday [7 February].
A journalist who worked for privately owned Al-Dustour newspaper and freelanced for news website Masr Alarabia, was shot in the head while covering clashes in the northern neighbourhood of Ein Shams.

SOURCE: Xinhua; Reporters Sans Frontieres; Aswat Masriya (Egypt)
NOTES: Egypts Al-Youm Al-Sabea newspaper said that one of its editors was injured by shots fired by police officers in clashes between security forces and students outside Cairo University.

SOURCE: Arabic Network for Human Rights Information
NOTES: A police sergeant beat photojournalist on his head, which resulted in injuries to his head causing him to bleed before being transferred to the hospital. Skirmishes took place between a number of the newspapers journalists and a number of police secretaries from the other. As a result, five of the newspapers journalists were wounded. Afterwards, the sergeant along with a number of police secretaries besieged the newspapers building.

A South Sudanese journalist was attacked by an unidentified group on Monday [11 August]. The attackers are said to have been a mixture of South Sudanese, Egyptians and others. Some South Sudanese internet sources have speculated that the victim was targeted due to his work of being a journalist.

Police forces assaulted and briefly detained two photojournalists from private newspaper Al-Masry Al-Youm and two other journalists on Sunday night, as they were covering protests in Abdel Moneim Riyadh Square.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Egypt (2014-) Prison Guards
NOTES: A photojournalist detained in Abu Zabal Prison was allegedly beaten by prison officers. A report was filed on 8th December, actual date of incident not specified.

On the night of 22 January 2015, several members of the Homeland Security - Egypt's main domestic security services - and of the General Investigations Department - the Criminal Investigations Department - broke into the home of a freelance journalist in 6th of October City, 30km west of Cairo. Without showing any warrant, they searched the rooms and confiscated his computer, mobile phones and identification papers before arresting him. Brought to the Security Forces camp of Sheikh Zayed, he was detained incommunicado and tortured for two consecutive days to force him to confess to crimes.
Four photojournalists and one reporter were injured as a result of birdshots, in addition to three who were assaulted and beaten whilst covering protests in Cairo.
Security agents stormed the home of a journalist in Cairo, confiscated his cell phone and laptop, blindfolded him and escorted him to an unknown location in an enforced disappearance.
Assailants attacked an Al-Ahram Foundation bus and injured at least six people on the road to 6th of October City.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Egypt (2014-) Prison Guards
NOTES: A journalist imprisoned in Tora Prison on charges relating to his conversion to Christianity over seven years ago was severely physically beaten and subject to verbal abuse.
A 23-year old freelance photojournalist was reported by her family to have been snatched on June 1 by security forces from a street in downtown Cairo, along with two male friends.

Two freelance photojournalist were announced missing Tuesday after disappearing since Monday near the Maadi Nile Corniche, in south Cairo, in more arrests and forced disappearances across Egypt. Approximately 150 people were arrested in the Maadi proximity that night.
Two journalists were forcibly disappeared by homeland security from their prison cell in Tora Prison.

Security forces seize a journalist from his house in Toukh, Qaliubiya governorate, seizing his laptop and mobile phone. The continuation of his detention and the unknown location of his detention is considered a forced disappearance.

An Egyptian photojournalist was found dead in the village of Abu-Taweela, in North Sinai on Monday. The circumstances around the death are unclear but it comes 10 to 15 days after he disappeared from Al-Arish.

A photojournalist was found dead in the city of Sheikh Zuweid. He was found along with at least six other bodies in the same area. The cirumstances surrounding his death remain unknown, although North Sinai militants known as 'State of Sinai' kill civilians for allegedly being 'army informers'.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Egypt (2014-) Prison Guards
NOTES: On 20 September a prison guard at Tora Prison beat a freelance journalist and his co-detainees up, and confiscated their blankets.

Masked and armed Egyptian security forces raided the office of an organization in Cairo that trains and aides journalists on 21 October. The forces detained all staff members present in the office of the Mada Foundation for Media Development and the Journalists Syndicate accused security forces of kidnapping two of its members, considered an enforced disappearance.
A journalist from Al-Nahar newspaper was forcibly disappeared by Egyptian security forces on 23 October on his way to the Cairo International Airport for a trip to London.

A photojournalist was reportedly stabbed by an unknown assailant with a penknife in downtown Cairo on 25 December in an 'assassination attempt'. The attack took place on the pedestrian bridge of Cairo University metro station.

A journalist was arrested on 30 December 2015 and detained on charges of forming an illegal political movement called Youth of 25 January. He was allegedly tortured until he confessed to his crimes, according to Arab Network for Human Rights and Information (ANHRI). The location of his detention remained unknown for several days following his arrest.

A Yanair Gate journalist was arrested in Mohandesen on 31 December and was taken to the Dokki police station. The National Security Apparatus detained the journalist for 72 hours without disclosing his location. His defence lawyer claimed he was tortured and severely beaten during interrogating.

Masked security agents wearing civilian clothes and police uniforms raided a the home of a journalist in Damietta at dawn on 21 February, arrested the journalist, seized his laptop and his mobile phone, and took him away in a police vehicle. Four days after his arrest, he reported that he had been subject to torture by electric shock on four separate occasions and that security officers had pressured him to confess to crimes he did not commit.
MP Mahmoud Khamis, an independent MP, assaulted a journalist in an attempt to prevent the media from interviewing MP Tawfik Okasha, after he was dismissed from parliament.

The families of detained protesters were assaulted while waiting outside a Cairo court for a verdict on 19 April. As security forces escorted the detainees to the prisoner transport vehicle among a crowd of relatives and activists, a group of women - likely to have been commissioned by an unconfirmed party - attacked all women and girls present, particularly targeting young photojournalists. The police did not intervene to stop the assaults. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders][women targeted: relatives of targeted groups or persons][women targeted: girls]

On 25 April, security forces detained at least 17 journalists in downtown Cairo, while others were assaulted, when military and police conducted sweeps to detain potential demonstrators and to close streets leading to the site of a planned protest at the Journalists Syndicate. The street protests demonstrated against a deal handing control of two Red Sea Islands to Saudi Arabia.
A reporter covering the clashes between rioters and police in Imbaba, was assaulted by the police, and then arrested along with scores of relatives and residents from the neighbourhood.
Three journalists who were arrested outside the Journalists Syndicate were beaten and electrocuted while in custody.

Two journalists, Hassan al-Bana Mubarak and Mostafa al-Aasar, disappeared as they were heading to their work place in Dokki. The families believe that there sons disappeared forcibly. One of the two is reportedly held in National Security HQs in Giza province.

On Dec 17, in Cairo, 4 journalists from Al-Masry al-Youm, El-Watan and Youm7 were assaulted by the Pharmacists Syndicate security team while covering the union elections. 15 other journalists were allegedly detained inside the headquarters. They were injured, and their materials destroyed.

On Jan 27 and 29, Police Forces abducted at least 6 activists in Cairo, Giza and Daqahlia after they attended a commemoration of the 2011 Revolution at Karama Party headquarters. On Jan 29, an Egyptian photojournalist was also abducted by Police Forces at Cairo Airport. They were taken to an unknown location

On Jan 27 and 29, Police Forces abducted at least 6 activists in Cairo, Giza and Daqahlia after they attended a commemoration of the 2011 Revolution at Karama Party headquarters. On Jan 29, an Egyptian photojournalist was also abducted by Police Forces at Cairo Airport. They were taken to an unknown location
On March 4, two brothers of opposition member and tv host Moataz Matar, their wives and children were abducted by Police Forces in Nasr city. The day before, police also raided his mother's house.

On April 22 (or before, unclear), in Alexandria, while traveling in a microbus, journalist Abeer Al Safati was arrested by policemen. Police stopped the car and required passengers to vote for the referendum but she refused. Her whereabouts remain unknown. [women targeted: voters]

SOURCE: Al Masry Al Youm (Egypt); El Fagr News
NOTES: On May 7, in Cairo, in Sada El-Balad news website's headquarters, journalists were assaulted by film-maker El Sobki and a number of his security guards following an alleged dispute between the newspaper and the film-maker. 3 journalists were injured and several goods damaged.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Egypt (2014-) Prison Guards
NOTES: On 26 November 2019, members of the National Security Agency beat a female journalist they arrested after she refused to give them access to her phone. Between 26 November 2019 and 18 December 2019, she was then subjected to torture at Qanater Women's Prison in Ashmun (Ashmun, Menoufia).
Victims were journalists MwanaHalisi Editor Saed Kumbena and Ndimara Tegambwange
Journalists were targeted for beatings by police as they broke up a demonstration deemed illegal, led by Chadema MPs in Arusha.
Police kill journalist while trying to disperse Chadema supporters
Journalists complain that police harass and assault them when they covered a story about Uamsho leaders facing charges
Police raid home of journalist and shoot him during the raid. The police claimed the shooting was accidental, but the victim disputes this
Community radio journalist found murdered in a forest; motive for murder may be related to his work as a journalist
Unidentified group attacks journalist outside his home
A group armed with machetes and pistols invaded a CUF meeting at Vina Hotel and attacked journalists who were covering the event with all sorts of weapons. 3 people were injured.

Around 15 November 2017, a group of unknown people kidnapped a journalist from Aga Khan, owned by Mawanchi Communications, in Kibiti (Rufiji, Pwani). The journalist was covering security operations against the militant operations in the area before leaders crossed over to neighboring Mozambique. He is believed to be dead.
On 21 November 2017, a group of unidentified men in Kibiti (Rufiji, Pwani) kidnapped a Mwananchi Communication journalist. The journalist conducted reports on unexplained killings in the region.

On 21 April 2021, a group of Tanzanian Security Forces in Dar es Salaam (Ilala, Dar es Salaam) attacked a journalist of Mwananchi Communications. The journalist was beaten, dragged and forced to dive into sewage. His work equipment including the cell phone he used to photograph was damaged. The journalist was attacked while taking photographs of the security forces who were evacuating petty traders. No fatalities and/or injuries reported.

On 29 July 2020, a videographer was injured in a knife attack near the scene of a demonstration affiliated with the Black Lives Matter movement in Portland (Oregon). A group reportedly followed him and a few of his friends for several blocks, and after he confronted them, one person from the group stabbed him. The perpetrator has been arrested and is facing charges of second-degree assault. The victim suggests that people familiar with his work on Twitter and Facebook had alerted 'activists' about his presence at the protests, and that he was allegedly targeted because of 'his right-wing politics and activism.'
Norbert Zongo, an outspoken journalist against the government, and three other people were killed by an unidentified armed group. The killings are suspected to be political.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Burkina Faso (2014-2015) Presidential Security Unit
SOURCE: Xinhua; Media Foundation for West Africa
NOTES: Members of the Presidential Security Unit forced radio stations to shut down throughout the capital as they executed a coup at the Presidential Palace. Some journalists were also beaten on the streets as they tried to cover the situation.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Burkina Faso (2015-) Gendarmerie
NOTES: Guezouma Sanogo, journalist and president of the journalist association (AJB), was beaten up by a policeman while at the Peasant National Day in Kaya.

SOURCE: Actu Burkina; Burkina24; Wakat Sera; Fasozine; WAT FM; Aujourd8
NOTES: On 7 January 2020, unknown individuals carried out an arson attack against an investigative journalist in Ouagadougou by throwing a Molotov cocktail against his vehicle, no casualties recorded, but severe damages to the vehicle.

On 2 December 2020, unknown gunmen opened fire against the home of a journalist of state-owned RTB in Ouagadougou (Ouagadougou, Kadiogo). No casualties were reported and the journalist was absent at the time of the attack.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Uzbekistan (2016-) Prison Guards
NOTES: On 3 February, relatives of a jailed journalist declared that he had been victim of a torture and ill-treatment in Tashkent since his detention on 27 September 2017.

On 13 May 2020, a group of unknown individuals attacked a photographer of the Uzbek language internet newspaper Effect uz in Quva town of Quva district in Fegrana region during an investigative work in the area related to the demolition of a private house in the district. Attackers used pepper spray on the journalist upon contact, broke his personal car's windshield and rear windows, and stole his work camera. [size=group]
On 23 October 2020, a journalist was physically attacked with a truncheon by police officers in Tashkent city after a dispute over a possible violation of traffic regulation by the journalist.

On 28 March 2021, about 3 unknown masked individuals beat with a baseball bat a 29-year-old activist blogger and government critic Miraziz Bozorov at his residence near Yunusabad locality in Tashkent city resulting in his hospitalization with severe injuries. The victim is known online for his critical views of corruption in the state institutions, president's policies and decriminalizing homosexuality in Uzbekistan.

On 22 November 2021, a male official of the Ulugnor district branch of the Andizhan RES power supply company assaulted a female activist-blogger in the town of Oqoltin following her attempt to investigate excessive electric bill fees for the local farmers. The victim filed a police report after sustaining injuries. [women targeted: activists/human rights defenders/social leaders]

On 10 May 2018, armed groups known as Colectivo took over the Vargas Hospital in Caracas. The group closed the entrance of the Hospital and beat a journalist and workers, and destroyed press material. The group threatened the health workers to prevent them from participate in a protest that was planned for that day.

On 21 September 2018, members of the armed colectivos attacked two journalists with light weapons who were covering a protest outside the Ministry of Education in Caracas. The attack only seems to have been meant to intimidate the journalists. No injuries were reported.

On 23 October 2018, four security personnel from a University in Guarico beat up a journalist. The journalist was trying to cover the visit of the former head of FARC: The revolutionary armed forces of Colombia.

On 14 November 2018, an unidentified armed group attack journalists while they were covering the student election process at the Universidad of Carabobo in Valencia. The group was carrying weapons, pointed journalists with guns, and stole cameras.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Police Forces of Venezuela (1999-) SEBIN: Bolivarian Intelligence Service
NOTES: On 23 Jan, a Turkey journalist and a Venezuelan photograph were kidnapped by an unidentified armed group in Venezuela. After the kidnapping, the group gave both civilians to the state's forces SEBIN who released them on Friday 1 Feb.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Venezuela (1999-) GNB: Venezuelan National Guard
NOTES: On Jan 23, military officers attacked a reporter in Puerto Ayacucho, Amazonas state, who was covering the protests and the death of a protester. Officers took away his cell phone.

On Jan 23, in Valle de la Pascua, Guarico state, a correspondent of a national media was assaulted by security forces. The security forces tried to take his cell phone while covering the detention of a person in a march against the regime of Nicolas Maduro.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Venezuela (1999-) GNB: Venezuelan National Guard
NOTES: On Jan 23, in Plaza Madariaga, in El Paraiso, some officials of the Bolivarian National Guard attempted to steal the cell phone of a journalist from an international network when recording the arrest of a citizen who was demonstrating. In addition, they threatened the journalist to send him to jail.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Venezuela (1999-) GNB: Venezuelan National Guard
NOTES: On Jan 23, a journalist from a radio station was attacked and injured while covering a protest in Maracay, Aragua state. No intervention in the protest was reported, so this is assumed to be a targeted attack on journalists.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Venezuela (1999-) GNB: Venezuelan National Guard
NOTES: On Jan 23, National Guard officers in Zulia state briefly detained and hit a photographer and took away his credentials and camera.
On 28 January, 12 journalists from different national media were beaten by the Lara state's police who banned the access of these journalists to the stadium where the local baseball team was playing.

On Feb 6, 2019, a journalist reported that she was attacked by a Trujillo state police when she was covering an official act of the Nicolas Maduro regime. The journalist was taking a photograph of a militia-woman when the officer tried to take the phone from her.
On 6 March 2019, a journalist and Chavist dissident was found beaten up on the side of the road and brought to a hospital where he later died. He had been missing since February 28.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Venezuela (1999-) FAES: Special Action Forces
NOTES: On March 14, 2019, in Bello Monte, Caracas, Special Action Forces (FAES) officers attacked and arrested a Polish journalist from the newspaper, Gazeta Wyborcza. The journalist was beaten. No further information.
On Mar 17, suspected pro-government militiamen attacked journalists and others who were waiting for the visit of the UN Human Rights Technical Commission in a hospital in Barquisimeto, Lara state.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Government of Venezuela (1999-) National Assembly; Journalists (Venezuela)
NOTES: On Mar 26, armed groups kept 9 deputies and 14 journalists in the National Assembly in Caracas besieged. More than 20 people stole equipment and telephones from international media photographers covering the ordinary session of the Assembly and tried to attack politicians in the vicinity of the legislature.

On October 07 2019, in Maracay, Aragua state, police officers attacked three journalists when they were reporting a hospital emergency room fire. It is reported that police officers forced reporters to delete the videos and hand over their ID card.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Venezuela (1999-) DGCIM: Directorate General of Military Counterintelligence
NOTES: On November 19 2019, in Dos Caminos, Sucre municipality in Caracas, journalists were attacked by Directorate General of Military Counterintelligence (DGCIM) officials inside the headquarter of the digital portal, Entorno Inteligente. Six journalists were arrested and released hours later. The motive of the attack is not reported. No fatalities reported.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Government of Venezuela (1999-) National Assembly; Journalists (Venezuela); VP: Popular Will
NOTES: On January 15 2020, in front of the building of the National Assembly in Libertador municipality, Caracas, members of Colectivos attacked with urine and feces opposition deputies and journalists. The Popular Will (VP) party issued a statement declaring that Colectivos attempted against the life of opposition leader, Juan Guaido. No injuries are reported.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Venezuela (1999-) FAES: Special Action Forces
NOTES: On March 21, 2020, in Mamera, Libertador, Caracas, Special Action Forces (FAES) entered the house of a journalist, threatened him, and took him. His father was hit in the head by the officers while trying to protect him. The event took place after the journalist released information about the spread of the coronavirus in Venezuela. The journalist was detained and sent to to the FAES headquarters in Caricuao.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Venezuela (1999-) FAES: Special Action Forces
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Journalists (Venezuela); PSUV: United Socialist Party of Venezuela
NOTES: Around 21 August 2020, in Cabimas, Zulia state, 10 Special Action Forces (FAES) officers attacked and killed two journalists, who were also members of the PSUV political party, in the Los Cocos sector. The motive of the attack is not reported. 2 fatalities.

Around 22 July 2021, in Giradot municipality (Aragua), a reporter was killed and his body found on the road to Choroni. The victim had been reported missing since 16 July, but no further information is available about the perpetrators or motives of the death. 1 fatality.
The Houthis reportedly abducted two members of Suhayl channel in Sanaa'a university.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Yemen (2015-2016) Supreme Revolutionary Committee
NOTES: On March 5, the Houthis kidnapped two journalists working for Akhbar al-Youm daily. Reporters Without Borders on Wednesday condemned what it called the 'increasing harassment' by Shiite Huthi militiamen controlling the Yemeni capital of the country's media.
Unknown people kidnapped a broadcaster and took him to an unknown place.

ACTOR1: AQAP: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
NOTES: March 18 - A prominent journalist and leading Houthi activist was assassinated in the capital Sana'a on Wednesday. A Two men riding a motorcycle approached the journalist and opened fire, striking him in the head. Al Qaeda later claimed responsibility for the attack.
Unknown armed men reportedly kidnapped a female Yemeni journalist in front of her house in the 30 street in Sana'a.

ACTOR1: AQAP: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
NOTES: AQAP armed men reportedly detained a person in Al-Mukalla city suspected of being a journalist for the Al-Masirah satellite channel which is affiliated with the Houthis.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Yemen (2015-2016) Supreme Revolutionary Committee
SOURCE: International Federation of Journalists; Yemen Data Project
NOTES: Houthi popular committees kidnapped 9 journalists in the Dream Land Hotel of the capital Sanaa, Amanat al Asimah governorate.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Yemen (2015-2016) Supreme Revolutionary Committee
NOTES: On 28 August 2015 a journalist was arrested by members of the Huthi forces at his home, also in SanaaÃ¢âÂ¬Ã¢âÂ¢a. His family told Amnesty Internationalthat he had been tortured during his detention. There are no formal charges against him but his family suspect he is being detained because he worked for the al-Islah aligned Suhayl Channel, which was raided in September 2014 by the Huthi forces and eventually shut down in March 2015.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Yemen (2015-2016) Supreme Revolutionary Committee
NOTES: A journalist, member of the Nasserist Unionist People's Organisation, was abducted from Dhamar by the Houthis and subjected to torture. He was hit by batons and metal bars, his leg was crushed and right elbow broken. He was refused medical treatment.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Yemen (2015-2016) Supreme Revolutionary Committee
NOTES: Houthi popular committees kidnapped at least 25 civilians, including political activists, human rights defenders and journalists, while they were attending a meeting in a hotel in the city of Ibb, Ibb governorate.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of Yemen (2015-2016) Supreme Revolutionary Committee
NOTES: After 211 days of detention and torture, the Houthi-Saleh Coalition has released Yemeni human rights activist. In October 2015 he, along with 28 other activists and journalists, was arrested at a meeting for the planning of a march requesting authorities to provide the besieged city of Taiz with drinking water. The majority of the group had been released after a few days, while six people, who were believed to be the main organizers, including the journalist, remained in incommunicado detention at the Political Security Prison, currently controlled by the Houthi-Saleh Coalition.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Military Forces of the United Arab Emirates (2004-); Private Security Forces (International)
